item.title: Are you doomed to have your mum’s menopause experience? Experts break down the link between genes and symptoms
item.dc:creator: Sophie Cockerham
item.content:encoded:
Once only referred to as ‘The Change’ in hushed tones, the conversation surrounding menopause has opened up considerably. While it’s encouraging that society has cottoned on to the fact that women don’t just disappear after 50, there’s still a lot we don’t know about menopause.

And with questions such as ‘Will I have the same menopause as my mother?’, ‘Will I go through menopause at the same age as my mother?’ and ‘How much of menopause is genetic?’ all ranking high on Google search, it’s clear that many of us are concerned that our own experiences will mimic those of our mother’s.

When I asked my mum about her menopause journey, she quickly put my mind at ease: “If there’s any truth to menopause symptoms being hereditary, you should be in for an easy ride. Or a fairly easy one, at least.”

Somewhat reassured, I still want to know just how much I can base my future on my mum’s experience. And what about the women who weren’t as fortunate as my mum – and perhaps, therefore, me?

Tess is one such woman who feels frightened about how her mum’s negative menopause experience might predict her own.

“Mum’s menopause came on in her mid-50s,” she tells Strong Women. “In hindsight, I realise that she had no real idea what was happening. She has no sisters and her mum died young… we didn’t know what she was going through either.

“I remember coming back from a study year abroad, and she appeared to be really ill. She’d convinced herself that the hot sweats and disordered thinking was malaria, as my dad had recurring bouts of it from his time in India and the symptoms seemed similar. The local GP eventually refused to see her as he became so frustrated with her theory, so she was left to struggle on with iron pills and the offer of valium. This was the late 80s when they could do such things.”

Tess says that because menopause was such a taboo subject both societally and at home, her mum was left to struggle alone for years. She now wonders if that fact played some role in her mother’s early onset Alzheimer’s diagnosis.

“Fast forward to more enlightened times, I was very conscious of how the menopause might affect me, particularly as I’d had bad postpartum depression. As soon as symptoms like brain fog, hot sweats and insomnia started to arise, I got myself assessed and prescribed hormone replacement therapy (HRT). That has kept my brain and body functioning so that my family don’t find themselves living with a stranger.”

Lianne, 37, relates to Tess’s worries. “The women on my mum’s side of the family always seem to suffer horrifically with their symptoms and end up having a hysterectomy,” she says. “I’m just at the start of my perimenopause journey but as I have PCOS, I know that it’s only a matter of time until the symptoms really rear their head.”

And while others may not suffer with exactly the same symptoms as their mothers, they’ve found themselves beginning the process at roughly the same age. Anna, now 41, began having menopausal symptoms aged 38 – two years earlier than when her mum’s periods “turned off like a tap” at age 40.

All the women on my mum’s side have hysterectomies

Lianne

“At the time, mum didn’t think it could be menopause. She thought she was pregnant so went to the doctor a number of times,” explains Anna, now a coach for menopausal women looking to navigate their careers through the period.

“She was always very open about her experience and it deepened my awareness of what to expect. But despite telling my doctor this history when I began suffering debilitating symptoms at 38, I was still considered ‘too young’ to be menopausal. It took 10 months to be diagnosed and treated.”

Despite her mum sharing her experiences, Anna says that she “really wasn’t prepared for the impact symptoms would have” on her career or as a mother to two small daughters. “The only similarity between me and mum was our age: my mum experienced the more physical side of menopause – particularly hot flushes. For me, anxiety was the most prominent symptom.

“When it began four years ago, I lost all my confidence, experienced nightly insomnia and palpitations alongside headaches, flooding, bloating and mood swings.”

<\h2>

While the anecdotal evidence seems to suggest that there is some truth that symptoms are hereditary, what does the science say? Are we really all ‘doomed’ (or blessed) to follow the same patterns as our mothers?

Dr Semiya Aziz, a GP, says that menopause and the symptoms accompanying it are influenced by a myriad of factors – not just your genes.

“Your personal health is a factor, including diet, exercise regimes, sleep routines, relaxation measures and habits such as drinking and smoking. Even your life circumstances come into play, as we know that stress can make everything in the menopause much worse,” she reveals.

“While there is no definite way of predicting the age at which menopause begins or vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes and night sweats) may occur, there may be a hereditary component – but this differs across races and ethnic groups, suggesting that the symptoms of menopause that women experience may be affected by multiple genes.”

According to The Study Of Women’s Health Across The Nation – a multiethnic, longitudinal, cohort study of US women that includes non-Hispanic Caucasian, African-American, Chinese, Japanese and Hispanic women – vasomotor symptoms were more prevalent in African-American and Hispanic women and were also more common in women with a greater BMI. Vaginal dryness was present in 30-40% of participants, and was most prevalent in Hispanic women.

<\h2>

Lifestyle factors

Dr Aziz continues: “You might have an earlier menopause if you smoke, if you live at a high altitude, have undergone certain types of surgery or radiotherapy to the pelvic area or have taken some types of chemotherapy drugs.”

Menopause anxiety

She adds that taking note of what your mother went through might “create a self-fulfilling prophecy and influence the symptoms you may begin to experience during your menopause”.

“Unfortunately, the understanding of genetic factors that influence women’s health and their menopausal experience remains limited – but just like no two humans are the same, every woman’s menopause experience will be unique to her body make-up.

“From the limited evidence we have on genetics, it is clear that our mother’s menopause isn’t always a predictor of what our menopausal experience will be,” she concludes.

Inherited habits

Sarah Williamson, a nutritional therapist, menopause expert and co-founder of WomenWise, agrees with Dr Aziz. “Often the timings of menopause are similar, as can be found in the Genetics Of Early And Normal Menopause study,” she says.

“However, most often, similarities exist because we keep many of the habits passed on to us by our culture and family upbringing, such as those around diet and exercise. Our genetics only account for a tiny percentage of our experience – so understanding your genetics and then making changes is a really powerful tool when it comes to menopause.”

Insulin sensitivity

She says that underlying health is the biggest factor affecting the menopause journey. “In particular, your level of insulin sensitivity (your ability to fuel your cells rather than preferentially storing food as fat) and your stress resistance are two key markers we look at,” Williamson explains. “Low iron levels and low thyroid function can mimic menopausal symptoms of fatigue, low mood and thinning hair – so ruling those out is important.”

In other words, it’s likely that the menopause experience we will go through is only tenuously linked to our genetics – which might come as a relief to women like Lianne and Tess, whose mums had a tough time.

<\h2>

Georgina Sturmer, an MBACP counsellor specialising in helping women to navigate this transition, tells Strong Women: “It’s crucial that the voices of women who are worried about a family history of bad menopause are heard. Don’t suppress these fears – explore them. They might be linked to your memories of how you experienced your own mum when she was going through menopause. The good news is that society is better equipped these days to support women through menopause. Openness is more encouraged, and treatment has become more sophisticated.”

And while there may be little we can do to stop the inevitable, there are thankfully ways we can try to alleviate some of the symptoms and break the cycle of yet another generation suffering the same menopause as their mum.

It’s a natural transition… it doesn’t have to be a car crash

Sarah Williamson

Eat a plant-rich diet

According to Dr Aziz, several studies show that healthier dietary patterns (eg a Mediterranean-style diet) may help to reduce the frequency and severity of vasomotor systems, as well as help to manage body weight and body shape changes that menopause can cause.

“The evidence suggests that incorporating a diet that is rich in fruit and vegetables, whole grains, beans and other pulses, and has a higher proportion of healthier fats from foods such as oily fish, nuts and seeds, may help with symptoms,” she continues.

“And certain foods and drinks can trigger and worsen menopausal symptoms. For example, it is suggested to steer clear of spicy foods that often contain the heat-producing compound capsaicin, which makes hot flushes worse. Both caffeine and alcohol can increase blood flow to the skin and can make you feel flushed, so it may be worth considering swapping your morning coffee for a herbal tea.”

Keep on exercising

“A variety of different types of exercise, including cardio workouts, resistance and weight training and gentle pilates or yoga, may be beneficial,” she says. “A study at Liverpool John Moores University found that women who followed a gym-based 16-week exercise programme developed fewer hot flushes compared with a group who did not exercise. One theory behind this was that being physically active could make your internal temperature controls more efficient.”

Prioritise relaxation and stress relief

Relaxation measures – such as mindfulness and meditation – can help in lowering the stress hormone cortisol, which may have several beneficial metabolic effects within the body, as well as helping aid sleep.

Williamson adds: “We can absolutely break the menopause cycle earlier in our lives. It’s a natural transition… it doesn’t have to be a car crash. Getting things like gut imbalances and mood issues sorted before you reach the transition will be very powerful.”

Dr Aziz concludes: “Benefits may be gained by ramping up your diet, exercise programme and taking some ‘me time’ in your 30s, as it may be that you will suffer fewer menopausal effects in the future. It’s never too early to start.”

item.title: Is poor mental health linked to hormonal imbalance? Here’s what the experts say about hormonal and mental wellbeing
item.dc:creator: Lisa Bowman
item.content:encoded:
We’ve got over 50 different hormones travelling around the bloodstream at any one time. Many of us blame random teary outbursts on them, but the truth is, we quite literally couldn’t live without our hormones. And for us to feel happy and healthy, hormones need to be balanced; most of them affect our mental health in some way or another.

But just how simple is the link between hormonal balance and mental health? If we’re struggling with low mood, is that necessarily linked to a hormonal mismatch? And if we’re experiencing an imbalance, is that necessarily going to result in an altered mental state?

<\h2>

Hormones like cortisol, serotonin and oestrogen all play a huge role in how we’re feeling, and their levels constantly fluctuate throughout the day.

“Raised levels of the stress hormone cortisol can affect neurotransmitters in the brain, leading to imbalances in serotonin - your happy brain hormones,” explains Dr Shirin Lakhani of Elite Aesthetics and a speaker at Pause! Live.

“This causes an imbalance in the adrenal glands; when cortisol levels go up, less testosterone is made and that lowers libido. Lower levels of oestrogen (the female sex hormone) can also cause mood swings, brain fog, irritability and depression.”

<\h2>

Although we all have the same hormones, how much you produce of certain types will depend on your sex. Females might experience hormonal imbalances on a monthly basis as part of the reproductive cycles, when using birth control or during pregnancy, perimenopause and the menopause.

However, sleep also plays a huge role in the normal functioning of the endocrine system, which explains why we often feel grumpy and hungry when we’re tired.

“Many hormones are dependent on the sleep-wake cycle, so not sleeping properly can cause hormonal imbalance,” advises Dr Lakhani.

“When you sleep, your cortisol levels naturally decrease. However, when you don’t get enough sleep they remain elevated, leading to lower levels of serotonin and testosterone.”

Research shows that hormonal imbalance can also cause sleep disturbance, creating a vicious cycle. It can also affect our menstrual cycle, fertility, appetite and metabolism.

<\h2>

Low mood and anxiety are both common symptoms of hormonal imbalance, as well as sleep disruption, fatigue, trouble concentrating and changes in appetite.

“However, these symptoms can overlap with other conditions, so it’s important to diagnose the root cause of the problem,” advises Dr Bruce Dorr, senior medical advisor for Biote. “Different symptoms of hormonal imbalance manifest for each patient and the frequency and intensity of symptoms vary as well.”

Low mood and anxiety are both common symptoms of hormonal imbalance

PMDD (premenstrual dysphoric disorder) is the more extreme version of PMS, which may be caused by changing hormone levels.

“There’s still little research around PMDD, but it’s thought that lower levels of oestrogen can occur during the luteal phase of the cycle, which happens around day 15 when the uterine lining begins to thicken,” explains Dr Lakhani.

“This can lead to increased appetite, depression, irritability, fatigue, headaches and trouble concentrating.”

<\h2>

In the first instance, if you feel persistently unwell or suspect hormonal imbalance, you should always speak to your GP, who can make a formal diagnosis, with a blood test being the most common way to check. However, there are lifestyle changes we can all make that help to keep hormones in balance and our general health in check. (And no, it’s not as simple as eating raw carrot salad, as some TikTokkers would have you believe…).

“There are many things in life that we can’t control – genetics, relationships, job/work stress—so what we can do is make sure that we are optimal in the areas that we can control,” advises Dr Dorr.

“Getting exercise – even if it’s just walking daily – and connecting with other people helps establish feelings of balance.

“Adequate sleep helps hormone restoration and resetting the mind, so we should avoid triggers before bedtime like computers, television and phones in order to get our best sleep.”

Dr Dorr also recommends “avoiding inflammatory and highly processed foods” in a bid to bolster the hormone receptors we have throughout our body.

“Fluctuations in glucose levels can be similar to those associated with anxiety and depression. Increasing good fats in our diets, such as essential fatty acids (found in oily fish and chia seeds), can help to reduce depressive symptoms, as up to 80% of our brain is made up of these compounds.”

These all might seem easy on paper, but our busy lives often mean that something as simple as going to bed at a sensible hour can be a struggle. So, if you’re feeling overwhelmed, try making one small adjustment at a time. And remember, it’s always a good idea to speak to a medical professional rather than self-diagnosing. Mood, mental health and hormones are complicated areas and you’re far more likely to rebalance the books by being properly assessed.

“Hormone imbalance can cause a wide range of symptoms and many people may be suffering without realising it’s due to a hormonal issue,” advises Dr Lakhani.

“However, there may be other causes of the symptoms so it’s important that you’re properly diagnosed in order to obtain the correct treatment.”

item.title: The world’s healthiest communities eat bread – and these health benefits prove you should too
item.dc:creator: Daniella Gray
item.content:encoded:
It’s no secret that bread has been subject to a barrage of bad press, with diet culture having hammered home the message that it poses a threat to healthy eating for years.

Luckily, we’re in something of a pro-bread era. Just look at the sourdough obsession that started in lockdown; we might not be making it anymore, but every high street seems to now have a bakery offering it. Fancy sandwiches are huge on social media these days. Flatbreads seem to be the side dish these days.

And aside from being delicious, filling and (outside of east London) quite cheap, there’s probably one main reason that bread just keeps coming back into fashion: it’s healthy. Along with other high-fibre foods, it’s a diet staple for the longest-living people in the world who can be found in what’s called the ‘blue zones’.

In Ikaria and Sardinia (two Greek blue zone islands), for example, breads are made from a variety of whole grains such as wheat, rye or barley – each of which offers a bucket-load of nutrients (but more on that later).

“Bread made from whole grains is a good source of essential nutrients such as vitamins, minerals (including iron, magnesium and selenium) and antioxidants,” says Lisa Marley, a nutrition coach and sustainable plant-based chef.

Bread is also mostly made up of carbohydrates, which are your body’s primary source of readily available energy. Wholegrain, in particular, also contains fibre – two slices contain around 4.5g or around 15% of the daily recommended amount. And those slices are rich in key minerals including magnesium, iron, zinc, vitamin B3 and folate.

“Fibre is good for many areas of health, including reducing the risk of heart disease, and it’s involved in energy metabolism and a healthy nervous system,” explains Rob Hobson, a consultant nutritionist at Healthspan.

The fibre, antioxidants and other compounds found in whole grains have been shown to lower cholesterol levels, decrease blood pressure and improve overall heart health.

<\h2>

So, yes, bread boasts a load of nutritional benefits. Even with interest in gut health and fibre on the rise, people still seem to demonise the humble loaf. Here are some of the most common yeasty myths and the truth behind them:

Bread is nutritionally empty

While refined white bread doesn’t rank too high when it comes to nutrition, that doesn’t mean it’s devoid of goodness altogether.

“White bread contains a good source of certain nutrients as the white flour is fortified [the process of deliberately increasing the content of one or more micronutrients] to account for the nutrients lost through processing of the flour,” confirms Hobson.

Two medium slices of white bread still contain calcium, iron and folate, for example.

Gluten is inflammatory

Gluten causes problems for some people; coeliac disease affects around 1% of the population and symptoms include bloating, gas, constipation and pain in the abdomen. For those people, it’s definitely best to avoid gluten, but “the majority of people can tolerate it without any issues”, says Marley. Gluten sensitivity is also a thing and while uncomfortable, it isn’t anywhere near as dangerous as coeliac disease.

Unless you’ve got symptoms that can be directly correlated to eating gluten, it’s not a good idea to cut it out as doing so can lead to stressful and unnecessary restriction as well as potentially missing out on vital nutrients.

Whole grain is the same as wholewheat

Choosing what bread to buy at the supermarket is enough to give us analysis paralysis – there’s a lot of choice.

“Whole grain means that bread can be made from any whole grain kernel such as oats or spelt, whereas wholewheat bread is made from all of the wheat kernels that have been ground down,” explains Marley.

The verdict? Go for a seeded whole grain loaf as “it contains more fibre and also good fats from the seeds”, she states.

Bread causes digestion issues

We all know that person who says they can’t digest bread properly, but the truth is, if you’re eating a slice, you’re already looking after your gut nicely. “Whole grain varieties of bread are high in fibre, which can support a healthy gut through better transit of waste via the colon and help gut bacteria to flourish,” Hobson explains.

That said, conditions such as IBS can be more difficult to manage and it’s probably a good idea to talk to your GP or a nutritionist about ways in which you might be able to enjoy bread without any adverse issues.

<\h2>

You’re not going to have time to scan the labels on every loaf in the supermarket, so to make it easier, Hobson recommends buying “a good quality wholemeal loaf that’s been freshly baked rather than something overly processed with a long shelf life and extensive ingredient list”.

Marley agrees, and suggests a whole grain sourdough loaf. Because bread contains starchy carbohydrates, you may experience a rise in your blood glucose after eating it (which is a completely normal response), making you feel tired and lethargic. But sourdough tends to cause a slightly smaller glucose spike compared to regular bread. That’s because the fermentation process in sourdough bread helps break down complex carbohydrates, making them easier to digest.

“This slower digestion process helps avoid rapid spikes in blood sugar levels and provides a more sustained release of energy, which can help with maintaining stable energy levels throughout the day,” states Marley.

However, sourdough still contains starch, which inevitably heightens blood sugar. To stabilise the spikes, team your slices with protein, fats and fibrous toppings like egg and avocado, baked beans or peanut butter and banana.

item.title: This creamy vegan mac ’n’ cheese is packed with fibre and natural probiotics
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
Is there anything more comforting than a plate of creamy, crunchy mac ’n’ cheese? We think not – but it’s hardly the most nutritious dish in the world. This version, however, couldn’t be more full of gut-supporting fibre and probiotics.

Nestling among the macaroni pasta, you’ve got stacks of broccoli (rich in vitamin C and antioxidants), peas (a great source of plant protein) and cavolo nero (full of calcium, fibre and B vitamins). The creamy, cheesy sauce is made using probiotic-rich white miso – known to support the immune system and ward off infections – and lemon, a vitamin C powerhouse.

Want an even bigger nutritional bang for your buck? Once cooked, top this dish with a sprinkling of nutritional yeast, which will boost its vitamin B12 content and make it taste even cheesier. This recipe uses Julienne Bruno cream cheeses, which you can find from various stores like Planet Organic.

<\h2>

1x Julienne Bruno Crematta™

2x Julienne Bruno Superstraccia®

100g broccoli

40g cavolo nero

50g all purpose flour

500ml water

1 tsp sea salt

½ tsp black pepper

1 tsp mustard powder

1 tsp onion powder

1 tsp garlic powder

1 tsp white miso

1 tsp soy sauce

250g macaroni

100g frozen peas

¼ lemon zest and juice

2 tbsp tapioca starch

<\h2>

1. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, blanch the broccoli and cavolo nero for 2 minutes then plunge into a large bowl of cold water. Drain then coarsely chop before setting aside.

2. Preheat the oven to 200°C. Spoon out the tub of Crematta into a medium/large pan, and set over a medium heat until it begins to melt. Gently whisk until the Crematta is entirely melted and begins to bubble. 

3. Add the flour, constantly whisking to combine until the flour cooks off and the roux-style base is smooth and glossy. 

4. Pour the 500 ml of water into the pan while whisking continuously.

5. Turn down the heat, add half a tub of the Superstraccia and cook for 5 minutes allowing the sauce to thicken, whisking occasionally.

6. Add all of the seasonings then whisk vigorously to combine. Remove from the heat before stirring through the chopped greens, peas, lemon juice, lemon zest and macaroni.

7. Spoon the macaroni mixture into your oven dish or skillet. Mix together remaining Superstraccia with the tapioca starch before evenly topping the dish, ensuring it is spread completely to the edges.

8. Bake in the preheated oven for 30 minutes until bubbling, and the top is golden.

9. Finish under the grill on high heat for 5 minutes until the top is beautifully browned and beginning to char. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 10 minutes before serving.

Recipe and image courtesy of Farmer J.

item.title: Is TikTok’s obsession with carrot juice justified? Experts on its benefits for gut health and hormones
item.dc:creator: Kerry Law
item.content:encoded:
View

Another day, another TikTok health trend. This time, it’s carrot juice that’s being heralded as a golden elixir, with the #CarrotJuice hashtag getting well over 45 million views. Videos on the platform claim the juice is “gut healing”, “immunity boosting”, “hormone balancing” and can “leave skin glowing”. It’s enough to have you raiding Bugs Bunny’s lunchbox and making for the nearest Nutribullet.

But is this drink really the magic health potion TikTok believes it to be? We asked the experts to talk us through the real benefits of carrot juice and look at just how much we should be drinking to optimise our health.

<\h2>

“Carrot juice is rich in vitamins A, C and K, as well as minerals like potassium and manganese. These nutrients are essential for overall health, our immunity and for supporting healthy skin, nails and hair,” certified nutritionist Adele Johnson tells Strong Women. “Carrots are also packed with antioxidants including beta-carotene, which may help protect cells from damage and reduce the risk of chronic diseases.”

The health benefits of this juice can be boosted with the addition of ingredients such as ginger and orange. “Ginger is known for its anti-inflammatory and anti-nausea properties, while oranges add vitamin C, boosting your immune system in a quick and convenient way,” adds Johnson.

To optimise the benefits further, it’s a good idea to select organic carrots for juicing. According to the Pesticide Action Network, carrots are one of the UK’s 12 most polluted fruits and vegetables due to their ability to absorb pesticides. If you can afford them, choosing organic might help to reduce your consumption of bug-killing chemicals.

@theabeeee Def improved acne!! But im still dealing with old scarring :( as another positive note im not orange and dont hate the taste anymore!! But highly recommend! Recipe 1. peel and cut one carrot 2. blend it with a cup of water 3. strain the juice through a sieve 4. drink it :) #hyperpigmentation #skincare #skin #care #pigmentation #dark #spots #darkspots #skincare101 #skincareroutine #melanin #indian #desi #brown #indiangirl #desigirl #browngirl #brownie #melaninbaby #darker #sun #selfcare #skincaretips #skintok #clearskin #clear #hormonalacne#hormones#acne#activeacne#hormoneimbalance#hormonehealth#natural#auyvedic#ayurvedalifestyle #ayurvedalifetips #carrot#carootjuice#carrotjuice#carrothealth #health#wellness #juice #cleanse #clearskin ♬ original sound - 🕷️

Alexander Thompson, senior nutritionist at Holland & Barrett, believes consuming carrots in juice form is often a better option than eating them cooked.

“Cooking carrots will result in some losses to vitamin and mineral content, although this effect can be mitigated by choosing cooking methods such as steaming, stir-frying or by adding a source of fat, such as vegetable oil or butter, to improve absorption of the vitamin A content,” he explains.

“Raw carrot juice retains the full vitamin and mineral content, but juicing strips away the beneficial fibre content.”

And this is where social media’s carrot juice claims start to sound a little empty…

<\h2>

“Whole carrots have been found to have a prebiotic role, meaning the fibre found within carrots is a good source of fuel for the beneficial bacteria that resides within the gut. Furthermore, black and purple varieties of carrot also provide plant compounds called polyphenols, which also provide prebiotic effects,” explains Thompson.

But this applies to fibre-rich whole carrots. As soon as you juice them, which removes almost all the crucial fibre, the related gut health benefits are almost entirely removed too.

Juicing removes all the crucial gut-healthy fibre

<\h2>

As for the TikTok claims that carrot juice is good for balancing hormones, Thompson reiterates the links with gut health: “In terms of supporting hormonal health, the prebiotic effects of the fibre in carrots helps to support a healthy gut microbiome, which may then help to support normal oestrogen levels. However, this effect is not exclusive to carrots and the best overall effects will be achieved through ingesting a wide variety of whole fruit and vegetables.”

When it comes to supporting hormones at other life stages, Johnson says that “while carrot juice is generally good for overall wellbeing, it may not have a specific effect related to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle or perimenopause – drinking it won’t replace decreasing hormones”.

It looks like TikTok’s carrot juice fans have pounced on the health benefits of whole carrots and assumed they apply to carrots in any form. While raw whole carrots do contain the fibre needed to support hormones and gut health, this is missing in its juiced form – any claims that carrot juice does the same for our health as a whole carrot is a misleading leap too far.

<\h2>

You may have heard scary stories about vitamin A toxicity, and while it’s true that a high intake can cause nausea, dizziness, blurred vision and severe headaches, it’s usually via certain medicines or supplements. The vitamin A from carrots is created by the body converting carotenoids into vitamin A – and as the body is able to regulate this, toxicity isn’t usually an issue where carrots are concerned.

However, too many carotenoids will have one particularly interesting effect. You may have spotted ‘the carrot tan’ trend on TikTok gaining millions of views. Like rabbits possessed, white TikTokers are chomping their way through bags of carrots and gulping down carrot juice on the regular to achieve what they believe to be a sun-kissed glow.

@erinthumannn

i swear carrots give you a natural tan #carrottan

♬ original sound - Diego R

While the vitamin content of carrots can help promote healthy skin, the ‘carrot tan’ these maniacs are chasing is actually a sign of beta-carotene overdose. Johnson explains: “Excessive consumption of beta-carotene can cause a condition called carotenemia, turning the skin orange-yellow – but this is not dangerous.”

Drink or crunch through a sensible amount and carrot’s high beta-carotene content can be particularly beneficial for eye health. “It can reduce the risk of age-related macular degeneration and improve night vision, which many women note deteriorates in the menopause years,’ she adds.

<\h2>

Both experts recommend carrot juice for its vitamin and mineral content, but that it should be considered as one part of a varied diet full of whole foods.

“Drinking carrot juice can be a tasty and easy way to get more of your weekly intake of nutrients, but it’s important to maintain a well-rounded diet containing a variety of fruits and vegetables,” says Johnson.

And Thompson is keen to stress the fibre point: “While carrot juice is a great way to get essential vitamins and minerals into your diet, the juice form can contain less fibre than eating the whole vegetable. Limit your intake of carrot juice to one small glass a day and make sure that you support this with plenty of other fruits and vegetables throughout the day too.”
