item.title: Twilight at 15: Catherine Hardwicke on creating a cult classic and whether she’d return to the franchise
item.dc:creator: Jess Bacon
item.content:encoded:
It’s no small feat to establish a film franchise based on a book that is already treasured by millions. Back in 2008, director Catherine Hardwicke revolutionised the young adult fantasy genre with Twilight.

From her edgy debut in 2003 with Thirteen, Hardwicke went on to release Lords of Dogtown, her chronicle of the 70s skateboarding scene, before her new Toni Colette-driven dark comedy, Mafia Mamma. It’s a surprise to Hardwicke that the teen vampire romance became her most influential and commercial success.

Stephanie Meyer’s novel spoke to countless teen hearts and preyed on our endless desire for unconventional love story. The moment that Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) clocks handsome, aloof Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) in the school cafeteria, neither of them stands a chance. So begins the genre-defining romance, which paved the way for future female-led fantasy franchises such as The Hunger Games and Divergent. 

Though 15 years have passed since the film’s debut, Hardwicke recalls the experience with such energetic clarity and fondness that you’d be forgiven for thinking filming ended days, not years ago. 

“What a crazy phenomenon,” Hardwicke says, shaking her head as though still in awe of it’s success. “When I took the job, we did not know that it was going to be this big global, worldwide hit. It was just mind-blowing.”

When asked about Twilight’s timeless appeal and cross-generational relevance - including its newfound following on TikTok - Hardwicke says it boils down to our innate desire to be loved or the allure of “a dangerous, forbidden romance.”

Ingrained within the film is the addictive nature of their desire, as Edward’s hunger for Bella grows and their dangerous obsession with each other parallels the animalistic anomaly of a “lion falling in love with a lamb”. Naturally, this only makes him want her more.

“Rob and Kristen have so much powerful chemistry in the movie that you feel like you’re there,” she adds, “It’s something that Stephanie Meyer was great about putting it in the DNA of the book - their longing.”

To evoke that in the film, Hardwicke mapped the lovers’ proximity in every frame to build that vital sexual tension. “I had a chart to mark exactly how close they ever got – like, if a finger touched, or if a hand touched,” she says, “I knew exactly what happened and calibrated every moment. It kind of teases you through the film.”

Alongside the epic love story, Twilight is widely recognised for its iconic, melancholic, muted aesthetic, where all the warmth and colour seems to have been drained out. Bella’s world is every sad girl’s daydream.

Visually, it also illustrated the overcast location of Forks, which is integral to the book, as it’s one of the “foggiest and rainiest places in the whole continent” - a perfect retreat for vampires who sparkle in the sunlight.

Every directorial decision was made with a conscious effort to control the colour palette, from the filming schedule being weather-dependent, down to every minute wardrobe detail. The actors were intentionally styled in neutral, natural, earthy tones to mirror the wild landscape.

“If we were filming and the sun came out, we did not shoot,” Hardwicke said, “We’d have to go and build a little rain cave and shoot in there or there was an interior set that we could go to, like a cover set.”

Alongside the climate restrictions, their limited budget of $37 million (£32m) impacted the scope of Hardwicke’s vision for the film. “I wanted to shoot in the real Forks and La Push Beach, but we couldn’t afford that,” she says, “I also wanted to do this really neat underwater sequence, more of the ballet sequence, more action, but we could only afford this much… and it worked.”

Studios were sceptical about a Twilight adaptation (“Nobody wanted to make it!”), but Hardwicke was dedicated to transforming Meyer’s cherished story it into a captivating big-screen experience.

“Twilight was still growing in popularity as we made the film. We could read the comments online, search what scenes (like the meadow) or lines people loved and even had tattooed on their arms! We knew we had to get those right,” she reflects.

Reading is often an intangible, private experience at odds with the collective experience of cinema. It was important to Hardwicke that Twilight honoured the original story for the passionate existing fanbase.

“I had to take scenes that were beloved in the book – for example when Bella asks Edward, ‘How long have you been 17?’ and change it,” Hardwicke explains. “It was set in a car, and two people in a car, wearing a seatbelt, stuck in a seat is not the most cinematic visual. It’s quite boring. So I took it out and put it in the forest with this big techno crane swooping around. That way you feel the emotions too.”

She focused on creating a symbiotic relationship between the film and the novel, drawing out the themes and the essence of this epic-scale Romeo and Juliet-style love story in just over 120 minutes.

“The treetop sequence in Twilight is not in the book at all. But it’s all about how it feels,” she says, “What it’s like to be in love with this cool vampire, who is dangerous and fast? Let’s make a scene that feels like that.”

Those creative risks paid off at the box office, as Twilight made a staggering $407 million worldwide, making Hardwicke one of the most successful female directors of all time. Its monumental financial success left the ambitious director hopeful for the future of her filmmaking career.

“I immediately thought, ‘I’m going to get to do anything I want after this’. But that wasn’t the case,” she recollects. “At the time, people weren’t shining a light on female directors, so all the other Twilight movies were directed by men. The Hunger Games movies were directed by men, and Divergent too.”

Despite her passion for the Twilight franchise, Hardwicke chose to not return for the sequels, to focus on developing her original films. However, if she had returned, Hardwicke says she would have done things differently.

“I try to make a film in a personal way and I think they got less personal,” she says of the subsequent four installments, “I would have stayed with the tone that we created in the first film, where you’re more intimate with the characters.”

After Meyer published 2020’s Midnight Sun, a re-telling of the Twilight story from Edward’s perspective, it seems the Twilight universe may return to the big-screen in the future – and Hardwicke doesn’t rule out revisiting the franchise.

“Sure – I love it still,” she says, before offering a curveball for a new direction for the franchise. “I’d love to do it in outer space. That would be awesome.”

“I’d love to do something with it. I’m not against it, as I’m very interested in cool stories like Twilight and creating another world. I’m open to anything.”

For now, though, Hardwicke is at the helm of a new female-led dark comedy, Mafia Mamma. Each of her films might be “quite different” but the focus remains the same - to “just live in somebody else’s skin for a while”.

“I thought [Mafia Mamma] was kind of great,” she says, “This woman has been silenced and ignored. Her husband doesn’t really care about her, her son is ready to go away to college and her bosses are toxic men who don’t respect her voice. So the fact that she finally finds her voice as the film progresses is exciting.”

“We were also still filming during the pandemic, and I knew I wanted Toni Collette and for the film to be a fun, female empowerment story about a woman finding her voice and some cool revenge in there too.”

Mafia Mamma is available to stream on Prime Video from November 17.

Images: Courtesy of Catherine Hardwicke, Getty, Gilles Bensimon

item.title: Do darker days hamper gut health? Experts explain the role of shorter days on our microbiome
item.dc:creator: Kerry Law
item.content:encoded:
Now that we’re edging ever closer to winter, it feels like our time is constantly spent dodging other people’s colds and fighting against the urge to stay in bed. And it’s now that maintaining a healthy gut – essential for helping us cope with these seasonal health woes – can feel like a bit of a slog.

Getting up in the dark, sitting under artificial light all day and coming home in the dark (rinse and repeat until March) means there’s barely a sliver of natural daylight to be savoured. It’s this simple fact that could be why you’re feeling off-kilter.

A small pilot study by the University of British Columbia and the Women’s Health Research Institute in Vancouver, Canada, discovered that exposure to UVB light (naturally encountered via sunlight) may lead to beneficial changes in the gut microbiome. It’s the first time this link has been found.

For the study, one group of women took vitamin D supplements over three months in winter, while a second group didn’t. Then, both groups were exposed to three full-body UVB light sessions over a week. Researchers found that following UVB exposure, levels of vitamin D had increased in both groups by an average of around 10%. However, those with lower initial vitamin D levels recorded a greater increase following the UVB sessions.

Interestingly, the study found that repeated skin exposure to UVB light increased the diversity in the gut microbiota of the group who had not taken vitamin D supplements, raising it to the same level as the group who had taken supplements.

This may be a small study, but it has piqued the interest of the gut health community with experts, including those at Zoe, who are heralding it as a gateway to exploring the link between UVB light and the gut microbiota. A growing body of research is now joining the dots between gut diversity and sunlight via UVB effects on the skin microbiome.

This better understanding of the ‘gut-skin axis’ – ie how changes in the skin microbiome may be reflected in the gut microbiome, and vice versa – helps explain why some conditions appear simultaneously. People living with coeliac disease or inflammatory bowel disease may also suffer from psoriasis, for example.

<\h2>

Given that we enjoy fewer daylight hours during the winter, does that mean our gut health is more at risk right now? And if so, do we need to tweak our gut health routine to make up for the lack of naturally produced vitamin D?

Orla Stone, dietitian, nutritionist and gut health specialist at Deeply, explains that winter presents specific challenges for our gut health, which low levels of vitamin D will exacerbate further.

“In the colder months, constipation and bloating can be more of a problem,” she tells Strong Women. “This is down to the fact that people tend to move less and drink less water, both of which are important for keeping your gut moving well.

“If your body’s inner temperature drops, your digestion will slow down, so keeping warm is key for maintaining healthy digestion.”

If your body’s temperature drops, digestion will slow

Orla Stone

We may also gravitate towards certain foods. “Dark, cold days can encourage comfort eating and snacking on processed foods which, in turn, will reduce your intake of nutritious fibre-rich foods that help your gut bacteria to thrive. [This supports] many different aspects of your health, such as mood and immunity, both of which can be challenged over the winter months,” explains Stone.

We’re also ducking and diving our way along the obstacle course of coughs and colds. “Given that 70% of our immune cells reside in our gut, keeping our gut healthy in winter is so important for helping to deal with any infections,” says Stone.

“One particular nutrient that you need to focus on over these darker months is vitamin D, which appears to have positive effects on your gut microbiome and your immune system.”

<\h2>

Eat more natural sources of vitamin D

“Both vitamin D2 and vitamin D3 raise your blood vitamin D levels; however, vitamin D3 has been shown to be slightly better,” explains Stone. “Vitamin D3 is found naturally in foods such as egg yolks, oily fish (including salmon, mackerel and sardines), red meat and liver.

“Fortified sources use vitamin D2 and include some spreads, cereals, plant milks and yoghurts, and these can be useful for those who follow a vegetarian or vegan diet.”

Winter is also tailor-made for gut-friendly food choices. Soup and stew season makes it easier to fill your diet with 30 different plants a week, along with cold-weather favourites such dark chocolate and warming spices including cinnamon and ginger.

Take vitamin D supplements

“It’s very difficult to get sufficient vitamin D from food alone. Therefore, it’s recommended you take a supplement providing 10mcg (400IU) of vitamin D3 daily from October to the end of March,” says Stone. She points out that vitamin D3 can also be sourced from algae, so vegetarians and vegans can top up their levels with an appropriate supplement.

“Vitamin D is fat soluble so it’s best to take it alongside a meal containing some fat so that it’s easier for the body to absorb it,” she adds.

Dr Ross Perry, a GP and medical director of Cosmedics skin clinics, adds: “If we’re getting vitamin D naturally from the sun, we’re synthesising it during the day. [Therefore] supplements are better taken in the morning.”

<\h2>

Going outside in natural daylight

Dr Perry says: “We get most of our vitamin D from sunlight exposure around late March to the end of September. However, in winter, sunlight doesn’t contain enough UVB radiation for our skin to be able to make enough vitamin D, so we need to get this from food and supplements.”

A stroll around the park may not boost your vitamin D but it’s still a vital part of remaining healthy and happy in winter. Stone says: “There’s a bi-directional relationship between your gut bacteria and your sleep – the health of both is related to each other. Getting out for a walk in the morning light helps you feel more alert because it suppresses melatonin, the hormone that makes you feel sleepy, and stabilises your circadian rhythm so you fall asleep at the correct time and wake up less often.”

Using a sunbed

Google ‘Do sunbeds give you vitamin D?’ and you’ll be faced with pages of conflicting information. Yes, sunbeds do emit UV rays but, as highlighted by Cancer Research UK, the amount of vitamin D you gain is far outweighed by the risks of UV damage and skin cancer.

Switching on a SAD lamp

Surely your trusty SAD lamp can do the same job as the missing sunshine, right? Wrong.

SAD lamps don’t emit the all-important UVB light needed for vitamin D production. They’re designed to mimic sunlight and filter out harmful UV rays, which is why you don’t need to wear sunscreen when using one.

According to the NHS, there is mixed evidence that light therapy works, but it does add that some studies have found SAD lamps, particularly if used in the morning, can help regulate your circadian rhythms and boost serotonin which lifts mood and reduces stress.

Images: Getty

item.title: 7 expert tips for making outdoor exercise enjoyable during the winter months
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
When it’s dark, cold and wet outside, the last thing most of us want to do is head out for a run or walk.

Unfortunately, the winter months often give those of us looking to keep up an exercise routine little choice – between week-long storm fronts and temperature dips, the weather at this time of year can be relentless. If you’re training for a big event or just want to keep your fitness levels up, that can leave you with few options but to grin and bear it.

But the last thing you want to do is spend the next three months feeling miserable every time you lace up your running shoes or look out the window. Winter tends to drag on, and it can be hard to stick to an exercise routine that makes you groan with dread every time you think about it.

So, to help you navigate this conundrum, we asked a group of fitness experts for the top tips they swear by to make outdoor winter exercise enjoyable. Here’s what they had to say.

<\h2>

During spring and summer, you can get away with exercising in any old pair of shorts and T-shirt (as long as you’ve got a good sports bra). However, as the weather gets colder, you’ll need kit that will help to keep you warm and allow you to perform at your best.

“Kit is particularly important when it comes to staying motivated over the colder months,” explains David Wiener, a personal trainer from the fitness coaching app Freeletics. “Investing in high-quality cold-weather workout gear can make a significant difference: look for moisture-wicking, thermal and windproof clothing to keep you warm and dry.”

Wearing lots of layers will also allow you to stay comfortable throughout your workout as you warm up. “Layering also ensures adaptability in unpredictable weather conditions,” adds Adam Byrne, clinical fitness regional lead at Nuffield Health. Byrne recommends putting together an outfit consisting of three key layers: a moisture-wicking material, an insulating layer and a water and windproof outer layer.

“If it suddenly brightens up, you can take that insulative middle layer off and go with a T-shirt and jacket combination,” he says. “Ensure you’re opting for lightweight garments where possible to make carrying them easier.”

<\h2>

Cold weather makes your muscles extra stiff, so warming up is a must to protect yourself from injury. If you struggle with the transition from indoors to outdoors, warming up inside (in your kit) before heading out can make things feel less jarring.

If you’re running, make sure to pay particular attention to your leg muscles – dynamic stretching, jogging on the spot and a few star jumps will all help.

<\h2>

When the temperatures get really low, you might find the cold air can cause a bit of discomfort in your chest; the cold air hitting the respiratory system can cause feelings of tightness and irritation. However, there are steps you can take to prevent this, Byrne says.

Some things he recommends trying include:

  • Breathing through your nose instead of your mouth
  • Wearing a scarf or snood
  • Focusing on slower, deeper breathing
  • Slowing down
  • Aiming for longer, not faster
  • Wearing a mask-type face covering

<\h2>

If working out in the dark just isn’t your bag, then popping out during your lunch break could be a more realistic goal. Whether you’re WFH or in the office, heading out for a jog or walk around the block can make a real difference, says Sam Quinn, personal training lead at Nuffield Health.

“Even 15 minutes can have a host of benefits for your physical and mental health,” he says. “It can also be an effective way of beating SAD, which can often make us struggle with energy and motivation. Employers can also play their part in encouraging colleagues to take a break to get active.”

Scheduling in your workout by blocking out time in your calendar can help to ensure you take the time to get moving rather than getting distracted by an endless number of meetings (we’ve all been there).

<\h2>

There will always be days when you can’t quite face the lashing rain and howling wind, and that’s OK. Being realistic about what’s achievable – and celebrating the wins – can help you to stay engaged even when things don’t go quite according to plan.

“If you miss a workout, don’t let that derail your progress,” Wiener says. “Sometimes it will be simply too cold to work out outside or go for a walk, and that’s OK.”

<\h2>

Setting goals is motivation 101 – not only does it give you something to work towards, but it also means you can adopt a training plan or schedule that’ll help you monitor your progress.

A good place to start is ensuring your goals are specific, measured and achievable, Wiener explains. “Having a clear sense of what you want to achieve can keep you motivated, even when it’s cold outside,” he says.

Your goal doesn’t need to be something as big as running a marathon or doing 20,000 steps every day, either. Even a small goal – for example, improving your 5k time or trying to walk a certain distance over the course of the week – can help to keep you accountable and give you an extra reason for getting outside when you’d rather not.

<\h2>

Convincing yourself to swap your warm, comfy bed for the wet and windy outside isn’t easy, so giving yourself some extra motivation in the form of community can be hugely helpful.

“You can buddy up with a friend or family member, join a team sport or become part of a run club,” explains Hugh Hanley, head of personal training at PureGym. “Everyone has a different exercise that they enjoy, and by finding what is right for you and making it social, you are more likely to stick to it throughout winter.”

You could also try making your exercise sessions into more of an event by tagging on a coffee or brunch to the end of your run or walk – not only will it serve as extra motivation, but it’s the perfect way to warm up after you’ve been out in the cold.m

item.title: Can TikTok’s moon breathing trend really help you get your best night’s sleep ever?
item.dc:creator: Anna Bartter
item.content:encoded:
If you’re one of the 22% of people in the UK who has trouble getting to sleep every night, you’ve probably already tried a whole range of suggestions in your quest for quality shut-eye.

We all know how important a good night’s sleep is, impacting everything from our attention span to our physical health, so any methods of improving our sleep quality are always welcome. And it’ll come as no surprise that TikTok is responsible for many of the tips and tricks we are trying.

The latest phenomenon taking over the social media platform is a concept known as moon breathing. Also known as the moon piercing breath, or chandra bhedana, the yogic breathing technique is said to bring about a sense of calm and relaxation – making it ideal for pre-bedtime.

It has already garnered a huge number of likes, so it might be worth a try. But how does it work? Here’s everything you need to know.

<\h2>

Moon breathing is a variation of alternate nostril breathing that focuses solely on the left nostril. It’s a form of pranayama or controlled yogic breathing and involves holding your right nostril shut while breathing in and out through the left.

“Moon breathing might sound a bit out there, but it can be a really useful tool for those struggling with sleep,” says Rosey Davidson, a sleep consultant and founder of Just Chill Baby Sleep. “This practice focuses on consciously slowing down and deepening the breath, which engages our parasympathetic nervous system (responsible for rest and relaxation).”

But what’s it got to do with the moon?

The practice relates to the traditional Indian medicine theory of nadis, the body’s energy channels. The three principle nadis are ida, pingala and sushuma, with ida nadi being the channel located on the lefthand side of the body. This nadi is thought to have a moonlike nature and feminine energy, which is why this form of left nostril breathing has been linked to the moon.

<\h2>

We all know that breathwork is fantastic for promoting a sense of calm and alleviating stress, anxiety and tension in the body. Focusing on our breath encourages mindfulness, allowing us to let go of stress, unwind and (hopefully) fall asleep more easily.

“Nostril breathing can help to prevent snoring, and it improves the immune system as our nostrils warm, filter and moisten the air we’re taking in,” says wellness consultant Tracy Richardson. “Nasal breathing can also help with dry mouth and teeth grinding.”

<\h2>

While research into the particular benefits of left nostril breathing is limited, we know that mindful, controlled breathing can have a powerful impact on our parasympathetic nervous system, also known as the side of the nervous system responsible for the ‘rest and digest’ state.

“By reducing the flow of air through our nostrils, we are increasing the carbon dioxide levels in our body, allowing for improved oxygenation of our cells, while calming our nervous system ready for sleep,” explains Jane Tarrant, breathing habit retrainer and educator at Link Breathing.

“By nose breathing, and even more so, single nostril breathing, we are increasing pressure to reach the bottom of our lungs, encouraging our diaphragm to stimulate our vagus nerve,” she continues. “The focus of this practice can also help calm racing thoughts through distraction and mindfulness.”

<\h2>

Luckily, moon breathing is one of TikTok’s more accessible trends. And studies show that it really does work, so grab yourself a pillow and blanket, get comfy and follow these steps.

  1. Find a comfortable seated or lying position.
  2. Bring your right hand close to your nose, keeping your elbow down. Inhale deeply through your nose, and count to four, allowing your abdomen to expand.
  3. Using your thumb, close your right nostril.
  4. Then, exhale through your left nostril counting to six, contracting your abdomen.
  5. Inhale through your left nostril.
  6. Next, close your left nostril with your ring or pinky finger.
  7. Exhale through the right nostril and inhale through your right nostril.
  8. Using your thumb, close your right nostril. Exhale through your left nostril. Inhale through your left nostril.
  9. You can also try alternating your breath between your nostrils – in through your left, out through your right, and vice versa, for around three minutes.

<\h2>

It’s not advisable if you’re congested or stuffy.

“Some people may try breathing through one nostril and find that they feel triggered to breathe more or it may result in a panicked, breathless or dizzy feeling after a few seconds or minutes,” warns Tarrant. “If this happens, you might wish to work on having optimal breathing habits during the day, gradually moving on to a night-time practice, or try another breathwork method.”

And even if it makes no difference to your sleep, moon breathing is a relaxing, calming end to your day, and we can’t ask for much more than that.

Images: Getty

When it comes to nailing a wardrobe that is both office and cool-weather appropriate, maintaining a laid-back approach to dressing is key, along with choosing staple pieces that you can easily throw together in a dash.

A poplin-button up shirt adds a little drama to your outfit, with voluminous silhouette, all while exuding professionalism. Just pair with wide-waisted trousers, black point flats and a red-stained pout. Obsessed.

item.title: Echoism is known as the opposite of narcissism, but it can be just as damaging – this is what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
Across the internet and in our IRL interactions, narcissism has become a buzzword. We fling the label of ‘narcissist’ at bad exes and look for signs of narcissistic personality disorder in our bosses, ticking off mental checklists and warning our friends to stay far, far away from anyone who shows a single narcissism-tinged flag.

What’s far less spoken about is the other half of relationships with a narcissistic partner: echoism. Often referred to as the opposite of narcissism, echoism is a collection of personality traits and behaviours that tend to be present in people who find themselves in partnerships with narcissists.

When an echoist meets a narcissist, things can go very, very wrong. So it’s important to know not only how to spot narcissism in others, but also how to notice echoism in ourselves. How do we do that? Let’s break it down.

<\h2>

“Echoism is a rather poetic term that was coined in 2005, borrowing from Greek mythology, to refer to when a person has given up their own identity in service of another person’s,” Lisa Bruton, psychologist and Counselling Directory member, tells Stylist. “Their whole being is oriented towards another person and they have completely lost touch with their own selves – their needs, wishes and wants.

“To be an echoist means you exist only in relationship to another and that you have yet to take possession of your voice– in the Greek myth it was Echo who lost the power of speech and was allowed only to echo the words of others.”

In short, if you’re an echoist, you’ll put other people’s needs and wants high above your own. Think of it as an extreme version of people-pleasing, where your entire self gets lost in favour of someone else.

“Echoism, in psychological terms, refers to a personality style characterised by a strong tendency to prioritise others’ needs over one’s own, often at the expense of personal wellbeing,” notes Dr Martina Paglia of the International Psychology Clinic. “Echoists exhibit traits of extreme self-effacement, an intense desire to avoid attention or acknowledgement, and a deep discomfort in receiving praise or recognition.”

<\h2>

Signs of echoism include:

  • Fearing praise
  • Fearing seeming selfish or narcissistic in any way
  • Excessively focusing on other people to the detriment of yourself
  • Neglecting your own needs
  • Struggling to create and maintain personal boundaries
  • Suppressing your own desires
  • Always agreeing with others
  • Avoiding or rejecting attention from others
  • Blaming yourself for everything
  • Being extremely self-critical
  • Struggling to assert yourself
  • Always needing to please others
  • Constantly making sacrifices for other people’s benefit
  • Never feeling good enough

<\h2>

As with so many things, you can blame your parents. Echoism often emerges from being raised by a parent with narcissistic tendencies.

“It is thought that echoism results from a toxic melange of a sensitive and attuned child, born into a household where one or all of the primary caregivers (typically the parents) have high narcissistic traits,” Bruton notes. “These caregivers exploit the child’s natural susceptibility to pay attention to the feelings of others, and set up a situation where to have their caregivers’ affection (crucial when you are young and highly dependent), the child needs to ‘feed’ the caregivers love of self and devote all their energies towards making the parent feel good and cared for. It is an example of reversed parenting (also known as parentification), where the child is doing for the parent what the parent should be doing for the child.”

Echoism is used as a way to try to ‘win’ attention and affection when it isn’t readily given. It can often be a sort of survival strategy – a way for someone to cope with an early relationship dynamic in which they didn’t feel secure.

An echoist exists only in relationship to another

<\h2>

Going about your life always putting your needs and wants at the bottom of the priority pile is, as you might expect, not great. The mental health impact is significant and the self-sacrificial, self-suppressing traits of echoists can mean they make decisions that set their life on a path that doesn’t fulfil them in any way, shape or form.

“Echoism can impact day-to-day living in many ways,” Bruton says. “At its core, it is a lack of relationship to the Self, to yourself. The internal dialogue of an echoist would typically be critical and self-abasing. They might shy away from anything that might bring them success, attention and praise. They might neglect their appearance and other aspects of adult functioning, such as pursuing career and financial goals, fitness goals, a rich social life. Basically, they have signed an unspoken pact that requires them to forgo any personal success if they want to be in relationship.”

“Echoism can impact daily life by causing difficulties in asserting one’s needs, neglecting self-care, fostering unhealthy relationships and contributing to stress, low self-esteem and communication challenges,” says researcher and relationship expert Limor Gottlieb.

<\h2>

Within the context of a relationship, echoism can cause a seriously toxic dynamic; especially if an echoist is paired with a narcissist. The problem is: echoists tend to be attracted to narcissists, and narcissists tend to be attracted to echoists. Oops.

“Echoists often find themselves in relationships with narcissists due to their tendency to put others’ needs above their own,” Paglia tells us. “This dynamic can be damaging because the narcissist’s self-centred behaviour further reinforces the echoist’s tendencies, creating an unhealthy cycle of dependency and imbalance.”

An echoist will want to give up everything to please their partner, while a narcissist will all too happily take, take, take. The end result is a narcissist is emboldened to ramp up their unhealthy behaviours, and an echoist is encouraged to continue suppressing themselves to let the narcissist shine.

Bruton explains: “The narcissist will exploit this excessive selflessness, and bleed the echoist dry of all their internal resources. Indeed in the myth, Echo stands by Narcissus until his death, at which point she turns to stone – a vivid metaphor to show that she had no internal ‘fire’ of her own.

“The echoist will find a natural ‘home’ with a narcissist, but this is in fact the unfortunate marriage of two dysfunctional positions. Rather than push back on the echoist’s excessive giving, the narcissist might in fact exploit and encourage it. The echoist is back in a very familiar role but one that leaves them empty and depleted, neglecting their own lives. From the outside it might seem like a perfect fit, but in fact neither party is learning to be in a relationship in a healthy way.

“The echoist is often very defensive of their partner, displaying the loyalty they might have felt as a child toward their parents. They are so out of touch with their own limits that they may not realise when they are tired from emotional caretaking, need to look after themselves more, and set boundaries, for instance.”

“Echoists prioritise the needs of narcissists, who seek admiration and validation. This imbalance can result in exploitative behaviour, a lack of reciprocity, self-neglect, low self-esteem, self-blame, cycles of abuse, isolation, and difficulties in leaving the relationship,” Gottlieb adds.

<\h2>

“If one recognises signs of echoism in themselves or their partner, it’s crucial to seek therapy or counselling to address underlying issues,” Paglia shares. “Working on building self-esteem, setting boundaries and learning assertiveness skills can significantly help in dealing with echoism. Both individual and couples therapy can be beneficial to navigate these challenges and establish healthier relationship dynamics.”

Echoist traits aren’t something to brush under the rug. You also shouldn’t assume that this is ‘just the way you are’ or think that you can continue in a relationship with a narcissist without making any changes – this isn’t healthy, and it’s a route not only to unhappy relationships but an unfulfilling life packed with self-doubt and constant questions about who you really are.

“Recognising and addressing echoistic tendencies is crucial for personal growth, self-esteem and building healthier relationships,” says Gottlieb. “Therapy and professional guidance can be valuable tools in the journey to achieve a more balanced and fulfilling life.”

Images: Getty

item.title: Apple TV+ shares a first glimpse of new Coco Chanel drama The New Look
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
Fashion can be a secretive and mysterious old world, especially for those of us not privy to the inner workings of the industry. Although mostly works of fiction, TV shows and films such as The Devil Wears Prada, House Of Gucci and The Assassination Of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story help to shed a little more light on what goes on behind the scenes of the fashion world. And now, Apple TV+ is adding another to our watch list.

Sharing the first glimpses of its new drama series The New Look, Apple TV+ will be debuting the 10-episode series early next year. Inspired by true events, the historical drama focuses on the stories of fashion designers Christian Dior, Coco Chanel and their contemporaries as they navigated the horrors of the Second World War and launched modern fashion as we know it today.

Here’s everything we know so far about The New Look.

What is the plot of The New Look?

Inspired by true events and filmed exclusively in one of the fashion capitals of the world, The New Look is set against the Nazi occupation of Paris during the Second World War and focuses on the “pivotal moment in the 20th century when the French city led the world back to life through its fashion icon Christian Dior”.

The official synopsis continues: “As Dior rises to prominence with his groundbreaking, iconic imprint of beauty and influence, Chanel’s reign as the world’s most famous fashion designer is put into jeopardy. The interwoven saga follows the surprising stories of Dior’s contemporaries and rivals from Chanel to Pierre Balmain, Cristóbal Balenciaga and more; and provides a stunning view into the atelier, designs and clothing created by Christian Dior through collaboration with the House of Dior.”

Who will star in The New Look?

Taking on the two leads, Ben Mendelsohn (The Dark Knight Rises; Secret Invasion) will star as Christian Dior with Academy award winner Juliette Binoche (The English Patient, Chocolat) as Coco Chanel.

The rest of the cast features Maisie Williams as Catherine Dior, John Malkovich as Lucien Lelong, Emily Mortimer as Elsa Lombardi and Claes Bang as Spatz.

Not only does The New Look feature a star-studded cast but the soundtrack will be produced by Grammy award winner Jack Antonoff and feature covers of popular early to mid-20th century songs performed by the likes of Florence Welch, Lana Del Rey, Nick Cave and many more.

When will The New Look be released?

The 10-episode series will make its global debut on 14 February 2024, with the first three episodes dropping initially on the streaming platform, followed by one episode every Wednesday until 3 April 2024.

Images: Apple TV+

item.title: Islamophobia Awareness Month: why it’s more important than ever to call out Islamophobia
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
“It’s just how some people react to people like us,” my mother told me when I was around eight years old, in response to me asking her why a strange man on the bus home from school was shouting at her. My mum wears a hijab – a headscarf – so she’s visibly a Muslim woman and has been subjected to her fair share of verbal abuse since my parents moved to the UK in the early 1990s. But how do you explain this to an eight-year-old who doesn’t understand why a person who’s never encountered us before suddenly decides to hurl abuse at a stranger on a bus? Sadly, this wouldn’t be the last time I came across what is now referred to as Islamophobia.

The term Islamophobia first appeared in public policy discourse in 1997, but it’s still not officially defined by the UK government. It was only relatively recently, in 2017, that a definition of Islamophobia was put forward by an all-party parliamentary group (APPG) but the Conservative party dropped its plans to give Islamophobia an official definition. But even without a state definition, it’s a type of racism that’s understood to target expressions of Islam or perceived Muslimness. And it’s on the rise.

As of March 2023, where the perceived religion of the victim was recorded, two in five (44%) of all religious hate crime offences were targeted against Muslims – making Muslims the most targeted faith group in the UK. But it’s certainly not new. In August 2018, having recently resigned as foreign secretary, Boris Johnson wrote a column for The Telegraph in which he compared women in niqabs to “looking like letterboxes”, which led to a 375% increase in Islamophobia incidents the week after the article was published.

But one thing Islamophobia is not is a ‘phobia’, despite its name. One of the most common things I’ve heard over the years when it comes to this form of prejudice is “But it’s not really racism, is it?” There are still misconceptions surrounding it. Islamophobia isn’t based on individual fear or apprehension, even though many people can regard it in this way. And when it’s understood in this context, it minimises the experiences of Muslims and frames this form of racism as a lesser version of hate and prejudice.

It can also imply that because of this fear, people have no control over their beliefs or behaviour, normalising Islamophobia and removing any type of accountability.

With this normalisation comes very real consequences for Muslim communities – from experiencing abuse and violence to dealing with prejudice and discrimination in the workplace. According to a recent Savanta ComRes survey, which asked 1,500 UK Muslims about their work and careers, seven out of 10 said they had encountered Islamophobia in a range of work scenarios, including engaging with customers or clients (44%) and at work-related social events (42%).

Another survey conducted by the University of Birmingham and YouGov in 2022 found that the British public is almost three times more likely to hold prejudiced views of Islam than they are of other religions. Muslims are also the UK’s second “least liked” group with 25.9% of people surveyed feeling negatively towards Muslim communities.

It’s why it’s more important than ever that Islamophobia is properly understood for what it is: a structural form of racism that targets a specific group of people for the simple act of practising a faith. And it shouldn’t fall on Muslims to constantly call out and stand against Islamophobia because we can’t push back on this normalisation without people outside of our communities also taking a stand with us.

  • A good starting point for accessing more resources is the official Islamophobia Awareness Month website which contains a range of information packs that you can easily download and access dependent on the context – if it’s your school, university or workplace.
  • The not-for-profit MEND (Muslim Engagement and Development) also has several resources and publications available to read, which includes guides, factsheets and toolkits.
  • It’s also worth engaging with prominent Muslim voices and their work – from books such as Cut From The Same Cloth and It’s Not About The Burqa to publications like Amaliah.

Whenever I encounter an Islamophobic comment or abusive behaviour, one thing I wish non-Muslims would do is call it out. It can be exhausting work for Muslims and our collective voices are always stronger together. In the end, solidarity is action and not just words.

Choose the right product, apply it with the right tool and you’ve got the perfect way to help perk up your face that’ll give you a healthy-looking glow with minimal effort required. 

Carefully buffed onto cheekbones and temples, perhaps even across the nose for good measure, cream bronzer melts into the skin and provides a supremely natural finish that adds a luminosity that you wouldn’t be able to achieve with a powder bronzer.

But, we get it, knowing which cream bronzer is best isn’t always easy. You want something that’s going to complement your skin tone in a subtle way that doesn’t look orange or dirty. item.title: Rumour has it that Adele is working on her own beauty brand – here’s everything we know so far
item.dc:creator: Lucy Partington
item.content:encoded:
In case selling over 70 million albums, having a residency in Las Vegas and just generally being one of the most famous singers of our time isn’t enough, Adele is now rumoured to be adding yet another string to her bow, this time in the form of a beauty brand.

Following in the footsteps of other famous founders, including Victoria Beckham, Lady Gaga, Hailey Bieber, Rihanna and Scarlett Johansson (who, can we quickly add, are all living proof that celebrity beauty brands can be good) it seems Adele is finally ready to stop gatekeeping exactly how we can recreate that famous smoky cat eye of hers, the one that we all love so much.

While we don’t have many specific details just yet, current word on the street is that the singer has filed for a trademark for a variety of different products under the brand name The Shelbourne Collective.

We are yet to know what that might mean or where it comes from, but there is every chance that – like Bobbi Brown’s Jones Road – it might not have any special significance whatsoever.

The list of prospective products is thought to include both eyeshadow and eyeliner, which makes sense given Adele’s go-to make-up look, as well as everything from lipstick and lip balm to body care and perfume.

There’s no mention of anything from Adele herself yet, which sadly means we don’t have any intel as far as a release date goes – and we probably won’t for a while – but we have our fingers crossed for a 2024 launch. And believe us when we say that you’ll be the first to know as soon as we hear even the smallest of details.

Watch this space.

Images: Getty

item.title: 4 ways to boost your wellness and soothe your seasonal stress this winter
item.dc:creator: Shadé Owomoyela
item.content:encoded:
For some, the approach of the festive season brings flashbacks of last-minute gift shopping, obligatory multi-generational get-togethers and busy calendars.

And if we’re not rushing around trying to make sure everything is in order for Christmas, we’re fretting about the new year and the trials and tribulations it might bring. But what if we told you there’s a way to avoid the stress of the festive season and ease into this wonderful time of year as cool as a cucumber?

Lined with all manner of shops and glittering with the oldest Christmas lights display in London, Regent Street and St James’s are perfect for seeking some much needed rejuvenation amongst the chaos.

From the sanctuary-like vibe of Third Space Soho to the homely atmosphere of Fortnum & Mason, here are our favourite spots to boost our wellness and soothe seasonal stress this winter…

<\h2>

When the last item on your list of things to take care of is yourself, the festive season is likely to be nightmarish.

But there’s nothing a good pamper can’t fix and at MASAJ, based in Quadrant Arcade, you can book yourself in for a bodywork session that’s bound to leave you feeling peaceful and refreshed.

Priding themselves on the transformative power of touch and ensuring all of their clients feel nurtured, it’s a fantastic studio designed to help Londoners let go of the stresses of inner city living. With a treatment list targeting relaxation, deep tissue, specific focus areas, sports massage and pregnancy massage, there’s something to soothe everyone.

If you’re feeling in need of an extra little treat after you’ve finished over at MASAJ, head to French chocolatiers Prestat in Princes Arcade. Founded by the family that invented the chocolate truffle, it’s the perfect place to enjoy beautifully crafted chocolate. Whether you opt for the classic milk chocolate thins or pick up a jar of heavenly hot chocolate flakes is completely up to you.

<\h2>

While it’s virtuous to focus solely on giving at this time of year, a little bit of self-love goes a long way.

And what better way to give yourself some proper TLC than with a little trip to the shops for some much needed self-gifting.

As clichéd as it may sound, buying yourself flowers is the perfect way to treat yourself with something that feels wholesome, and St James’s florist Bulbous has a gorgeous selection of blooms for you to choose from.

Or, if you’re more of a cosy homeware girlie, the Earl Of East is stocks the best independent fragrance brands, homeware and accessories. What started out as a humble market stall in 2014 is now three bricks-and-mortar stores across London with its own line of sustainable fragrance and bathing products. Plus, if you love a truly creative experience, they host candle-making workshops and serve coffee to create a space that goes beyond a shopping destination and fosters community.

The Body Shop is a favourite amongst body care enthusiasts and the perfect place to treat yourself to some gorgeous-smelling pamper products. If you’re really getting into the self-gifting spirit, choose one of their gift sets to wrap up and pop under your tree to open on Christmas Day.

So, if you your love language is receiving gifts, don’t wait for somebody else to step up when you can fulfil it all by yourself.

<\h2>

One of the best ways to stay on top of your wellbeing at this time of year is to keep your body active and moving.

Third Space Soho is a new kind of health club committed to creating an atmosphere that nurtures the mind, body and spirit. If you like an intense fitness routine, step into Third Space’s hypoxic chamber – a room that simulates high-altitude conditions – and push your body to its limits. If you prefer a gentler approach to movement, you can immerse yourself in the four-lane, 20-metre pool or stretch out in one of their yoga classes.

You needn’t go far to find a club with a team of specialist coaches and medical practitioners to help you on your fitness journey either. Get pumped to improve your physical and mental wellbeing at COACH London, where jiu-jitsu, physiotherapy and psychotherapy are just three services in their extensive fitness and wellbeing offering.

Want to look super-stylish while working up those endorphins? GYMSHARK is your shop for high-performance sportswear and training accessories. They also host free gym classes in the morning, so if you fancy a high-energy workout to start your day, keep an eye on their website to see what sessions they have coming up.

<\h2>

Based in St James’s, Fortnum & Mason is one of London’s most regal shopping houses. The 18th century department store is known for its gourmet picnic hampers and luxury tea and preserves, and it even has a restaurant and calendar of seasonal events. Mini marzipan mushrooms, Christmas cognac butter and the promise of a chef-hosted supper club? It doesn’t get more decadent than that.

Luxury fragrance brands, Molton Brown, L’Occitane and Aesop also reside on Regent Street and are the perfect spots to indulge your senses. Try out the Fiery Pink Pepper Pod range at Molton Brown and leave feeling invigorated or pop into L’Occitane for a bottle of the viral Hydrating Almond Shower Oil to bring a slice of luxury into your pamper routine.

Now you know exactly how to prioritise wellbeing this festive season, which spot in the rejuvenating wonderland of Regent Street and St James’s will be your first stop?

Ready to make this festive season your most relaxed yet? Head down to Regent Street and St James’s for everything you need to wave goodbye to seasonal stress. And if you want to see what else is on offer, visit Regent Street and St James’s online for more info.

Follow Regent Street on Instagram & TikTok: @regentstreetw1

Follow St James’s on Instagram: @stjameslondon

item.title: Exclusive: watch the official trailer for Paramount+’s The Doll Factory
item.dc:creator: Morgan Cormack
item.content:encoded:
Bookworms and TV watchers have been positively spoilt for choice when it comes to adaptations recently. Joining the ever-growing novel-to-TV-series pipeline is The Doll Factory. The UK wing of new streaming platform Paramount+ ordered an adaptation of the Sunday Times bestseller and it’s set to be a dark period drama about sisterhood and obsession.

As well as having the production company behind ITV’s Marcella attached to it, there’s also a host of behind-the-scenes talent making us very excited for the new six-part drama.

Here’s everything you need to know about The Doll Factory, including the official trailer.

What is the plot of The Doll Factory?

As mentioned, The Doll Factory will be based on the bestselling 2019 novel of the same name by Elizabeth Macneal. The book was enough to give us chills (and keep us looking over our shoulder when reading), so we’re excited to see if this new series will recreate the same eerie atmosphere.

According to Deadline, the series – like the book – will be set in London in 1850 and explores the story of Iris, who paints dolls for a living alongside her twin sister, Rose. She dreams of becoming an artist, and by night, secretly paints herself naked.

Silas is a taxidermist who owns a shop filled with his creations. He dreams of one day finding an item so unique he will be catapulted to fame. Louis is a painter and member of the pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, searching for his next muse, and he finds it within Iris.

Louis soon asks Iris to model for him, and she agrees on the condition that he will also teach her to paint, and suddenly her world expands beyond anything she ever dreamed of. Suddenly before her is the opportunity to escape and start a new life, but in doing so, she must abandon her sister, sacrifice her reputation and launch herself into the unknown. But as Iris’s world expands, a story of dark obsession begins to unfold.

We said it was a chilling one, didn’t we?

Who will star in The Doll Factory?

Esmé Creed-Miles (Hanna) will play Iris; Mirren Mack (The Witcher: Blood Origin) is her twin sister, Rose; Pippa Haywood (Magpie Murders) plays Mrs Salter; Éanna Hardwicke is Silas and Wedding Season’s George Webster plays painter Louis.

The series also stars Sharlene Whyte (Stephen), newcomer Reece Kenwyne-Mpudzi, Freddy Carter (Shadow And Bone), Saoirse-Monica Jackson (Derry Girls), Laurie Kynaston (The Sandman), Jim Caesar (The Witcher), Akshay Khanna (Chloe), Aysha Kala (The Undeclared War) and Nell Hudson (Outlander).

Independent production company Buccaneer Media is attached to produce the thriller and they’ve been responsible for other hit dramas such as Marcella and Whitstable Pearl.

Sacha Polak (Hanna, Dirty God) is on board as director, Suzanne McAuley (Magpie Murders, Maigret) is producer and Julie Harkin (I May Destroy You, Becoming Elizabeth) is casting director.

When and where will The Doll Factory be available to stream?

The Doll Factory will be available to stream on Paramount+ from 27 November, with all episodes released on 1 December. In the meantime, watch the official trailer below.

item.title: “My boyfriend told me he wanted to become an ‘alpha male’ – it ended our relationship”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Burrell
item.content:encoded:
It was Valentine’s Day 2023 that Ruby*, a teacher in her early 30s, realised something was different about her boyfriend. They were heading to the gym, as they often did, before a date at an art exhibition in the evening. 

“He was usually a really helpful coach,” she explains. “I was struggling to get a new exercise right that day, but when I called over for help – as I normally would – he snapped in a way I’d never seen before. He shouted at me across the gym: ‘It’s not my job to help you, you shouldn’t expect so much of me.’ I was really shocked and like, woah, where has this come from? We left the gym, immediately afterwards he said to me: ‘You really need to go away and reflect on the fact that you’re displaying codependent toxic behaviour’.”

To say this came out of the blue is an understatement, Ruby tells me. At that point, Ruby and her boyfriend had been together for the best part of a year, during which she “couldn’t have asked for a better relationship”. They’d met on Hinge, where Ruby was delighted to find a guy who was her type, shared her interests and made references to attachment styles in his profile. “He was studying philosophy and psychology as a mature student,” she says. 

“We had intellectual conversations and immediately set up a date, where we just hit it off straight away. Within a couple of months we were completely exclusive – boyfriend and girlfriend. All of my friends and family met him and were like, ‘oh my goodness you seem so happy, we’ve never seen you like this before, he’s great for you’. I thought I’d found the love of my life, my future husband and father of my children.”

We were having arguments once a week

But things changed that day at the gym. “Suddenly, we were having arguments like that once a week, twice a week. It just escalated very quickly,” says Ruby, who also began to notice that her boyfriend’s views about current affairs were shifting. “At some point while we were going out there was the Will Smith ‘slap incident’ at the Oscars. His opinions about that did register as strange to me – there was an emphasis on masculinity and what it means to be a man. He said that it sometimes means asserting yourself violently against other people to defend your woman’s honour. He was coming out with these more traditional, gendered ideals and I definitely questioned it, saying ‘I don’t agree’, but it was kind of like, ‘let’s agree to disagree and move on’.”

Ruby’s boyfriend’s behaviour only became more erratic and aggressive. “We were sitting in a pub having a Sunday roast and he just looked at me with his head tilted and said: ‘You’re so submissive, aren’t you?’” Around the same time, he began to ask questions like, ‘You’re scared of me, aren’t you?’ – and Ruby had a sense that he not only knew she was scared, he wanted her to be.

He said, I’ve come to the hard realisation that I’m an alpha male

Then came the statement that made her realise where this behaviour had been coming from. “Not long after the pub incident he said, ‘I’ve come to the hard realisation that I’m an alpha male and you can’t handle me, you obviously want a beta male’ and that was the ‘ding ding ding’ moment,” she says. Ruby’s boyfriend was referring to the myth of male hierarchy supposedly observed among animals like chimpanzees and wolves, in which ‘alpha males’ enjoy a position at the top with greater access to power and mates, while weaker, submissive ‘beta males’ are below them.

It was the summer of 2022 that Ruby’s boyfriend immersed himself in this kind of discourse, while waiting to start a Masters course and working ad hoc jobs making cold calls and doing manual labour. “He found it boring so he’d started listening to a lot of podcasts,” she says. “He’d shown me bits and bobs but it wasn’t until the start of this year that he would reference them and use them in arguments to justify opinions about our relationship.”

Ruby can’t remember everything he referenced, but she knows he started listening to The Joe Rogan Experience, and then followed offshoots from that, consuming content from guests on the show. The controversial Spotify podcast has attracted much criticism for offensive remarks, including sexist comments, racial slurs, misinformation about Covid and derogatory comments about trans people. Ruby’s boyfriend also mentioned content from Jordan Peterson, a Canadian psychology professor famous for his all red meat diet and YouTube videos that tell viewers what being an alpha male ‘REALLY means’. It’s all part of the deeply troubling online ‘manosphere’ community, a collection of men’s support communities that, at their most extreme, advocate aggressively misogynistic views, such as those expressed by self-proclaimed misogynist influencer Andrew Tate.

Ruby knew about this dangerous world thanks to Lily O’Farrell, the feminist writer and cartoonist (@vulgadrawings), who creates informative content about the online world. “I knew what I was dealing with after the alpha male comment,” says Ruby. But then, things got even stranger. “We’d just woken up on a Sunday morning and he was like, ‘So I’ve been hearing on this podcast about semen retention and how it’s going to be really good for me to hold onto my power’,” she says. He then explained that they could still have a sexual relationship but that he would ‘edge’, which means stopping stimulation to avoid ejaculation. “I looked into it and there are some wild videos that say a man’s seed is magical, which is why women are always trying to harvest it from them,” says Ruby.

“On some levels it [claims to be] about testosterone and building muscle, but then there’s a crossover into this spiritual world. He told me that ‘the abusive power of feminism was flowing through me and I was possessed and had an entity attached to me and needed to see a shaman to have it cleared’.” This conversation was the last straw.

“Now I can laugh about it because I can see it’s just completely ridiculous, but at the time it was disturbing because this was a person I was completely in love with,” says Ruby. “You know gaslighting – it works. I’d been in it for some time and I was, at that point, questioning my own sanity.” With the support of friends, family and colleagues, she was able to extract herself from the situation, breaking up with her boyfriend in a public place with friends waiting nearby. “One tip I would give is to talk to the people around you and not be worried about tarnishing your partner’s character in the eyes of your friends,” she says. “You need that reality check and the sounding board of other people.”

Another piece of advice she offers is to be aware of any new content your partner is consuming. “Without trying to be a private investigator or crossing a boundary, do some research,” she says. “I wish I’d been more willing to have those uncomfortable conversations and follow that line of enquiry.”

Of course, it shouldn’t have been up to Ruby to prevent this from happening, as Lily O’Farrell reminds us. “There’s a common narrative around abusive relationships – that you should have left sooner,” says Lily. “But the responsibility is on the online platforms that allow this harmful content to flourish, not the women in men’s lives. It’s not your fault if someone you love gets radicalised.”

Now, however, Ruby is attuned to all the warning signs someone might be getting involved in this world. “If people I encounter are giving strong hints – like reading Jordan Peterson, for example – I try really hard to listen and not confront them. I don’t think it’s helpful to be combative because from what I can tell, the people who get lured into this sphere are feeling rejected, insecure and vulnerable. But it can’t go unquestioned either. So I try to listen, be empathetic and ask questions.”

When it comes to dating, she approaches it with hyper-vigilance. “You’re worried about spotting those red flags. My current partner is having to be a bit more patient in terms of earning my trust, but that’s ok. The place to start from is trusting your intuition and knowing your worth. When you’re there, you’re not going to let anyone cross your boundaries or step on you. And then you can feel safe allowing people in.”

*Name has been changed

<\h2>

Ruby’s experience is all too common. If you, or someone you know, find yourself in a similar situation, psychologist and relationship adviser Barbara Santini shares five tips below.

“If you feel it’s too late and the relationship is no longer healthy for you, it’s important to have a plan to leave safely. Reach out to friends, family, or professional services that can provide support during this transition. Remember, prioritising your wellbeing is not selfish – it’s necessary.”

<\h2>

Communication is the cornerstone of any strong relationship. Begin with expressing your feelings without accusation. For example, “I’ve noticed some changes in your interests and I’m feeling concerned. Can we talk about it?” This opens up a space for understanding rather than confrontation.

<\h2>

Before approaching your partner, it’s essential to understand where they’re coming from. Familiarise yourself with the content they’re consuming. This knowledge will enable you to have a more informed and empathetic conversation.

<\h2>

Share your core values and ask about theirs. Questions like “What does being an ‘alpha male’ mean to you?” can lead to deeper insights into their aspirations and fears. Understanding these can be key to addressing the underlying issues.

<\h2>

Sometimes, these interests stem from insecurities or a lack of direction. Suggest working on self-improvement together, whether it’s through joint activities, counselling or seminars that promote healthy self-esteem and mutual respect.

<\h2>

If you believe the ideology is harmful, it’s crucial to set boundaries. Make it clear what you’re comfortable with and what you’re not. If they cross these boundaries, it may be time to reassess the relationship’s future.

Images: Getty

Ruby first shared her story on the podcast No Worries If Not, hosted by Lily O’Farrell

item.title: These are the best places to go beauty shopping in London
item.dc:creator: Lucy Partington
item.content:encoded:
Most of us do a lot of our beauty shopping online these days: whether it’s purchasing your go-to shampoo and conditioner during a flash sale, picking up a new bottle of your favourite foundation as part of a bigger Boots order or throwing a cleanser into a virtual shopping basket while you do your weekly shop.

It’s something that we’re guilty of doing, but there’s so much forgotten joy that can be found in the time spent slowly browsing independent beauty shops with friends, going from counter to counter in various department stores or visiting the standalone boutiques and temporary pop-ups that are home to your favourite brands, each one offering an entirely different shopping experience.

Being able to wander aimlessly, swatching, spritzing and sniffing as you go, speaking to sales advisors and learning about the products that are so beautifully displayed all around you – especially in the lead-up to Christmas – is something that shouldn’t be underestimated.

So, if you’re in the mood to refresh your make-up bag or treat somebody else, here’s our round-up of the best places to shop, enjoy and experience beauty in London.

Glossier Realms of You

Separate to Glossier’s standalone store in Covent Garden, Realms of You is an immersive pop-up experience that celebrates the brand’s bestselling fragrance, You. Designed by the brand’s in-house team, it features a series of rooms allowing visitors to experience the scent through each of the five senses. Open from 18 November though to 14 January 2024, there is, of course, exclusive merch available to buy, including a pepper grinder (inspired by the perfume’s notes of pink pepper) and a mini microphone to ‘amplify the sounds of you’.

Nearest tube station: Oxford Circus

Glossier Realms of You, 173 Regent Street, London, W1B 4JQ

https://www.instagram.com/p/Czq3cYUswmi/?img_index=1

Sculpted by Aimee

A brand that keeps going from strength to strength, Sculpted by Aimee is opening the doors to its first London boutique this week, and we couldn’t be more excited. The brainchild of make-up artist Aimee Connolly, the brand launched in 2016 and has seen exponential growth ever since. There are already two boutiques in its home country of Ireland, but this is the first in the UK. Here, you’ll be able to shop customer favourites, like Cream Luxe Blush and Second Skin Dewy Foundation, as well as booking in for make-up application ahead of big events.

Nearest Tube station: Oxford Circus

Sculpted by Aimee, 20 Fouberts Place, London, W1F 7PL

https://www.instagram.com/p/CzejRT2McKa/

Earl of East

A new addition to Quadrant Arcade, situated just off Regent Street, is Earl of East’s first beauty-focussed store. Known for its collection of home fragrance, bathing and self-care products, the shop also stocks a number of other carefully curated brands that align with its ethos, including AKT London, Guy Morgan and Mirror Water. Plus, you’ll find a selection of chic homeware, and you can even book in for a candle making workshop.

Nearest tube station: Piccadilly Circus

Earl of East, Unit 2, Quadrant Arcade, 80 Regent St., London, W1B 5RL

https://www.instagram.com/p/CxSnG7-IvS_/

Sephora

As of this week there are now two Sephora stores in London, the original in Westfield White City, but the newest addition is in Westfield Stratford City. Both offer a similar range of brands, including some that are new to the UK, like Patrick Starr’s One Size, Lady Gaga’s Haus Labs and Makeup by Mario, as well as Sephora Collection, but you’ll find others, like Salt and Stone, Naked Sundays, Adowah Beauty and Straand exclusively in Stratford so if that’s not a reason to hop on the Central line and visit both shops, we don’t know what is.

Nearest tube station: Stratford International

Sephora, Westfield Stratford City, 157 Montfichet Rd, Stratford, E20 1EJ

https://www.instagram.com/p/CzrBVUis-z9/

Jo Malone London

As well as having a number of idyllic stores dotted around the city, Jo Malone London is calling Glide at Battersea Power Station home for the festive season. As well as a riverside ice rink (open from 10 November through to 7 January), a 30ft tree adorned with classic cream boxes, there’s also an immersive Gingerbread Land experience where you can browse and shop the brand’s festive fragrances, as well as being able to customise bottles and boxes with bespoke personalisation.

Nearest Tube station: Battersea Power Station

Jo Malone London, Battersea Power Station Turbine Hall, Circus Road, London, SW11 8BU

https://www.instagram.com/p/Cmlm4oduuxI/?hl=en

PureSeoul Soho

If you want to shop K-beauty in real life, then PureSeoul is one of the places to visit. Jam-packed with so many innovative, exciting and must-try brands that aren’t readily available in many other brick-and-mortar stores. Plus, the friendly and knowledgeable staff are on hand to help you navigate the shelves.

Nearest Tube station: Leicester Square

PureSeoul, 70 Charing Cross Rd, London, WC2H 0BJ

https://www.instagram.com/p/Cc5InGrryzb/?hl=en&img_index=1

Malin + Goetz

What was only supposed to be a pop-up location for a few months, this store has been open for almost a year. On the ground floor you’ll find a selection of Malin + Goetz favourites, from candles to shower gel and hand cream, while upstairs is often transformed into experiential spaces. Formerly the rum room – to celebrate the brand’s much-loved Dark Rum range – it’s now been turned into the strawberry bar in honour of the newest fragrance franchise.

Nearest Tube station: Piccadilly Circus

Malin + Goetz Quadrant Arcade, Unit 1 80 Regent Street, London W1B 5RL

https://www.instagram.com/p/CxlOzsBRe2J/?hl=en&img_index=1

Liberty London

One of the city’s most iconic department stores, Liberty London is a treasure trove of beauty brands, both big and small. The smell when you walk in is enough to make you want to stay there for hours on end, just browsing and taking it all in. The Diptyque fragrance space is a candle lover’s dream and it’s worth stopping by just to experience that.

Nearest Tube station: Oxford Circus

Liberty London, Regent Street, London, W1B 5AH

https://www.instagram.com/p/CfeHZ2lONVt/

Les Senteurs

Home to a seriously impressive range of niche fragrance brands, Les Senteurs is one of the city’s hidden perfume gems that’s well worth a visit if you’re in town. You can browse, smell and explore in your own time, and the warm, seriously knowledgeable team will be on hand to help you out if needed. So if you’re looking for a new signature scent or for another fragrance to add to your collection, this is the place to go for something truly unique and special.

Omorovicza London Institute

Taking inspiration from the brand’s institute in Budapest, Omorovicza has opened its doors to the first London boutique. Combining the centuries-old wellness traditions that the brand is renowned for, there’s a menu of six Skin Therapy sessions based around traditional Hungarian massage – with one of them being exclusive to the London Institute – as well as a retail space to browse and purchase products recommended by your skin therapist.

Glossier

Following the success of its temporary pop-up, a couple of years ago Glossier opened a permanent flagship location in Covent Garden in what is said to be its oldest surviving building in the piazza – if you haven’t been yet, you’re missing out. Even if you don’t buy anything (but can we recommend checking out the exclusive merch or treating yourself to a Balm Dotcom), the store alone is an experience: decked out like a chic showroom, you can play with and discover products to your heart’s content, plus the huge mirrored entrance makes for the perfect Instagram-worthy photo opportunity.
