item.title: Is your hormonal imbalance genetic? 4 things a GP wants you to know about hormonal health and genes
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
When we talk about hormonal health, a lot of focus tends to be placed on what we can do to take back control. From hormone-balancing diets to menopause-friendly pilates routines, there’s plenty of practical advice out there for anyone looking to support their hormonal balance and alleviate uncomfortable symptoms.

However, that doesn’t mean your hormones are solely influenced by the lifestyle choices you make.

While external influences such as diet and exercise can play a role, they’re not going to completely transform your hormonal profile. Our genes, however, hold significant sway over our body’s hormonal system. Here are four key facts you need to know.

<\h2>

“Our genes provide the codes for the building blocks or amino acids that regulate enzyme and protein production that enable the body to make hormones,” explains Dr Ghazala Aziz-Scott, a GP, functional medicine expert and women’s health specialist at the Marion Gluck Clinic.

“These proteins are involved in hormone synthesis and production, transport (because the hormones are bound to proteins in the blood), sensitivity and detoxification.”

<\h2>

Several of our genes are involved in the hormonal response process – ie when hormones rise or fall in response to certain stimuli – so variations in these genes can also contribute to our overall hormonal balance.

According to Dr Aziz-Scott, a key example of this process is seen within the creation of the enzyme aromatase, which converts testosterone into oestrogen. If the gene responsible for creating this enzyme is upregulated – a term which simply means the gene is more active – more of the enzyme will be created and released, consequently leading to an increase in oestrogen levels.

Other genetic variations can also lead to an imbalance in oestrogen – or at least the symptoms that come with it. For example, if the genes that create your oestrogen receptors – the parts of your body which control your hormone sensitivity – have a certain variation, your body may become more sensitive to oestrogen.

“Oestrogen is also cleared from the body by a process called methylation, so if the genes involved in this are less efficient, oestrogen clearance can be affected and levels can rise,” Dr Aziz-Scott continues. “The expression of these genes can also be affected by environmental factors or epigenetics such as diet, lifestyle, ageing, stress, sleep, immune function and environmental toxins.”

This is one of the reasons why lifestyle changes can have a knock-on effect on your hormones; by influencing the genes which create the proteins that go on to become hormones, the whole system is affected.

<\h2>

Hormonal conditions such as PCOS can also be fuelled by certain genetic variations, Dr Aziz-Scott adds. This is on top of the environmental factors – such as diet and gut health – that have also been found to play a potential role. “PCOS runs in families,” she says.

The genetic variations associated with PCOS affect several different areas, including the body’s androgen receptors – a type of hormone which is typically elevated in people with PCOS. The receptors associated with the menstrual hormones (luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) are also affected, as is the receptor for leptin – the hormone which controls appetite and affects blood sugar control.

<\h2>

But the relationship between our genes and hormones doesn’t end here. Indeed, Dr Aziz-Scott highlights, your hormones can also have a knock-on effect on how your genes are expressed.

“Steroid hormones such as cortisol, oestradiol, progesterone and testosterone can bind to the intracellular receptors that affect gene expression,” she explains. “For example, cortisol receptors are present within many different cells throughout the body, so when cortisol levels rise, it changes the expression of thousands of genes that affect immune responses, metabolism, growth and many more processes.”

Hormonal health is clearly a lot more complex than adding a few new foods to your diet, so don’t get bogged down by content that makes it seem like you should have everything under control.

Educating yourself on the exact problems you’re facing – either by visiting a GP or hormonal health professional – is the best place to start if you’re experiencing uncomfortable symptoms, as they might be able to suggest specific lifestyle changes which could make a difference. Eating well, exercising regularly and getting enough sleep will also help to keep things ticking along – all of which will offer benefits outside the realm of your hormones.

Images: Getty

item.title: How to use eyebrow gel properly: keep brows full, fluffy and in place all day long
item.dc:creator: Morgan Fargo
item.content:encoded:
Eyebrow trends come and go. From thick and fluffy to those that are drawn on with military precision. Even the thin 90s-esque brows are slowly making a comeback into modern life. However you like yours, there’s no denying that the everlasting popularity of the full brow has brought with it myriad innovative inventions.

And, while I’m particularly partial to the type of eyebrow gels that come with a brush and can be used for my baby, flyaway and brow hairs, finding one that truly works has been a journey.

However, my research did lead to an interesting finding: the brow gel you choose is important, yes, but it’s the application that makes a sizeable difference, too.

Loading each eyebrow with gel before attempting to brush them into shape was something I had seen make-up artists do as second nature, but, somewhat foolishly, it wasn’t a technique that I adopted into my own routine until later than necessary.

Where before I would comb my brow up once or twice (and be inevitably disappointed when it fell down within the hour), taking the extra few seconds to massage the product into the hair made the world of difference.

The fluffy, full look I was attempting came true. And it lasted all day! Here’s what to do.

1. Clean the hair

Before you do anything to your eyebrows, take a cotton pad (reusable or otherwise), a towel or a face cloth and gently wipe any product from your eyebrows. If you do your eyebrows last in your routine, it’s likely other make-up –like foundation, powder or even skincare – will be on them and hinder how well the brow gel is able to adhere.

2. Brush the gel in every direction

Take your eyebrow gel wand, toothbrush or spoolie and coat it with the product. Then, brush it into the hair in a variety of directions, focusing on even coverage from the root to the tip of the hair.

3. Lay the hairs in place

Finally, brush the hairs into the shape you want. Try to avoid pulling a jumper or top over your head while your brows are drying, which could cause the hairs to become muddled and messy again.

Some make-up artists suggest holding the eyebrow in shape for up to 10 seconds straight afterwards to intensify the hold.

Images: Morgan Fargo

item.title: 3 snackable chocolate bakes to help you beat the 3pm slump
item.dc:creator: Stylist Team
item.content:encoded:
You’re working from home, the light outside is dreary, and the buzz of your morning coffee has well and truly worn off – yet there are still hours to go before you can log off. At these low-on-motivation moments, you might find your mind drifting to your snack supplies. What can you nibble on to give your afternoon a boost? What would go particularly well with your 3pm cup of tea?

There are plenty of answers to this question, and many of them can be found in Chocolate All Day, the new cookbook by acclaimed Australian chocolatier Kirsten Tibballs (one of the most-followed female pastry chefs on Instagram, incidentally). Focused on chocolate recipes that are “big on wow and low on difficulty”, Chocolate All Day contains easy-to-follow instructions for baking everything from chocolate babka knots to sticky date chocolate puddings.

Below, Tibballs shares three recipes for snackable chocolatey treats perfect for lifting you out of an afternoon slump. That means chocolate-chip cookie sandwiches with orange ganache; peanut cookie cups with chocolate caramel filling; and a caramel slice topped with milk chocolate ganache.

All of these recipes make a sizeable batch of treats, which can then be stored in an airtight container in your fridge for whenever you get peckish. The caramel slice and chocolate-chip cookie sandwiches will last for up to a fortnight, while the peanut cookie cups will stay delicious for up to a month. Honestly, though? We challenge anyone to resist polishing them off for that long.

Chocolate-chip cookie sandwiches with orange ganache

Kirsten says: “Make way for your new obsession. I’m talking chewy cookies with a lusciously smooth, melt-in-the-mouth filling with hints of crunch. A little bit fancy, and a whole lot of fun, these choc-chip cornflake cookies get a flavour boost thanks to a swirl of orange-infused chocolate ganache. They are a tantalising eating experience and an instant crowd pleaser.”

Makes 30

Ingredients

For the orange ganache:

  • 195ml (6¾ fl oz) thickened (whipping) cream
  • zest of 1 orange
  • ½ teaspoon vanilla bean paste
  • 430g (15¼ oz) good-quality milk chocolate

For the cookies:

  • 100g (3½ oz) raw sugar
  • 165g (5¾ oz) soft brown sugar
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
  • 115g (4 oz) unsalted butter, softened
  • 50g (1¾ oz) whole egg
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla bean paste
  • 155g (5½ oz) plain flour
  • ½ teaspoon bicarbonate of soda
  • 110g (3¾ oz) good-quality milk chocolate, roughly chopped
  • 110g (3¾ oz) good-quality dark chocolate, roughly chopped
  • 90g (3¼ oz) cornflakes, crushed

Method

To make the orange ganache, heat the cream, orange zest and vanilla in a saucepan over medium heat and bring to the boil.

Place the milk chocolate in a bowl.

Once the cream is boiling, strain it over the chocolate. Whisk until the chocolate is completely melted and incorporated into the cream.

Cover with plastic wrap touching the surface of the ganache.

Leave to cool at room temperature for 2–3 hours before transferring to a piping bag or snaplock bag.

For the cookies, preheat the oven to 170°C (325°F) fan-forced. Line a baking tray with baking paper.

Place the raw sugar, brown sugar, salt and butter in the bowl of a stand mixer with a paddle attachment and beat on medium speed until smooth.

Add the egg and vanilla and mix to combine.

Sift in the flour and bicarbonate of soda and mix until incorporated.

Remove the bowl from the mixer, add the chocolate and crushed cornflakes and stir them through.

Place the cookie dough in the fridge for 1 hour.

Roll teaspoonfuls of the dough into balls. Place them on the baking tray approximately 4cm (1½ inches) apart and gently press down on them to flatten slightly.

Bake for 10 minutes or until golden brown.

Remove from the oven and leave to cool at room temperature. Repeat with the remaining cookie dough.

To assemble, cut the tip off the prepared piping bag of orange-infused ganache.

Pipe the ganache onto every second cookie and sandwich them together with the plain cookies.

Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

The cookie dough can be prepared in advance and stored in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. Allow the dough to come back to room temperature before baking.

For best results

If your room temperature is warm, place the ganache in the fridge to firm it up to piping consistency.

Fix it

If the ganache looks grainy after you add the cream to the chocolate, add a tiny bit more cream and continue whisking.

Peanut cookie cups with chocolate caramel filling

Kirsten says: “Just when you thought a chocolate and peanut flavour combo couldn’t get any better. Here, a biscuity peanut butter base acts as a little bowl for lush honeyed caramel, with chocolate whisked through in the final step because, well… chocolate. Believe me, you will fall in love with these wickedly irresistible caramel cups.”

Makes 12

Ingredients

For the peanut cookie cups:

  • 85g (3 oz) unsalted butter
  • 65g (2¼ oz) soft brown sugar
  • 65g (2¼ oz) caster (superfine) sugar
  • 95g (3¼ oz) crunchy peanut butter
  • 30g (1 oz) whole egg
  • 125g (4½ oz) plain (all-purpose) flour, plus extra for dusting
  • pinch of baking powder
  • pinch of sea salt
  • 75g (2½ oz) good-quality milk chocolate, chopped

For the caramel filling:

  • 250ml (9 fl oz) thickened (whipping) cream
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla bean paste
  • pinch of sea salt
  • 185g (6½ oz) caster (superfine) sugar
  • 65g (2¼ oz) liquid glucose
  • 35ml (1¼ fl oz) water
  • 150g (5½ oz) unsalted butter
  • 25g (1 oz) honey
  • ½ teaspoon bicarbonate of soda (baking soda)
  • 75g (2½ oz) good-quality milk chocolate

Method

To make the peanut cookie cups, preheat the oven to 170°C (325°F) fan-forced. Grease a 12-hole muffin tin.

Using a stand mixer with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugars on medium speed until well combined and completely smooth.

Add the peanut butter followed by the egg and mix to combine.

Add the flour, baking powder and salt, then mix until almost completely incorporated.

Lastly, add the chopped milk chocolate and mix until the ingredients just come together as a dough.

On a lightly floured work surface, divide the dough into 12 even portions.

Place the pieces of dough into the holes in the tin, pressing them into the base and sides to form a cup.

Line each cup with scrunched then flattened baking paper, and fill with uncooked rice. Bake for 8 minutes. (This is called blind baking.)

Remove the paper and rice and bake for a further 10 minutes.

Leave to cool slightly. When the cookie cups are firm enough to handle but still warm, remove from the tin and leave to cool completely at room temperature on a wire rack.

Clean and dry the muffin tin.

When the cookie cups have cooled completely, return them to the clean tin.

For the caramel filling, heat the cream, vanilla and salt in a saucepan over medium heat until almost boiling.

Heat the sugar, glucose and water in a large saucepan over medium heat until the temperature reaches 145°C (293°F).

Reduce the heat to low, immediately add the butter and honey and whisk by hand to incorporate.

One-third at a time, pour the hot cream mixture over the caramel and whisk to combine.

Carefully add the bicarbonate of soda, then increase the heat and bring to 118°C (244°F) while whisking continuously.

Once the caramel reaches temperature, remove from the heat and immediately add the chocolate. Whisk until the chocolate is completely melted and incorporated.

Pour the caramel into the prepared peanut cookie cups and leave to set at room temperature for 1 hour.

Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 4 weeks.

Next level

This recipe can also make one spectacular large tart. Press the cookie dough into a fluted flan (tart) tin, then follow the recipe. Serve slices with fresh cream or ice cream.

The peanut cookie cup mixture can be used to make beautiful cookies.

Caramel slice topped with milk chocolate ganache

Kirsten says: “Just when you think caramel slice (sometimes known as millionaire’s shortbread) can’t get any better, I bring you this new level of decadence. What makes this caramel slice so good? Chocolate, of course. Here you’ll find it nestled in the biscuit base, humming in the caramel filling and crowning this slice in the form of a glossy ganache.”

Makes 18 pieces

Ingredients

For the biscuit base:

  • 125g (4½ oz) unsalted butter, melted
  • 200g (7 oz) soft brown sugar
  • 120g (4¼ oz) plain (all-purpose) flour
  • 50g (1¾ oz) desiccated coconut pinch of ground cinnamon
  • 50g (1¾ oz) good-quality milk chocolate, roughly chopped

For the caramel filling:

  • 80g (2¾ oz) unsalted butter, cubed
  • 80g (2¾ oz) soft brown sugar
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 395ml (13¾ fl oz) sweetened condensed milk
  • 90g (3¼ oz) good-quality dark chocolate

For the ganache topping:

  • 250g (9 oz) good-quality milk chocolate
  • 100ml (3½ fl oz) thickened (whipping) cream
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 30g (1 oz) liquid glucose
  • pinch of sea salt

Method

To make the biscuit base, preheat the oven to 160°C (315°F) fan-forced.

Grease a slice (slab) tin, 27.5 x 17.5cm (11 x 6¾ inches) and 3.5cm (1¼ inches) high. Line the base and sides of the tin with baking paper and set aside until required.

Put the melted butter and brown sugar in a bowl and mix with a wooden spoon to combine. Add the flour, coconut and cinnamon. Continue to mix until the ingredients come together.

Add the milk chocolate and mix to combine.

Press the mixture into the base of the prepared baking tin to create an even layer.

Bake for 15 minutes.

Remove from the oven and set aside at room temperature.

Reduce the oven temperature to 140°C (275°F) fan-forced.

For the caramel filling, combine the butter, brown sugar and vanilla in a saucepan over medium heat.

Once the butter has melted and the sugar has completely dissolved, reduce the heat to low, add the condensed milk and whisk continuously until the mixture begins to simmer. Continuing to whisk, cook for a further 3 minutes until the mixture begins to thicken slightly.

Remove from the heat and add the dark chocolate. Mix until the chocolate is melted and incorporated into the caramel.

Pour the caramel filling over the biscuit base and spread to create an even layer.

Bake for approximately 25 minutes.

Remove from the oven and leave the slice to cool completely at room temperature.

For the ganache topping, place the chocolate in a bowl.

Combine the cream, vanilla, glucose and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to the boil, then pour the mixture over the chocolate. Gently whisk until the chocolate is completely melted and incorporated into the other ingredients.

Pour the ganache over the cooled caramel layer and spread evenly. (For a less rich version, make the slice without the ganache topping.)

Place the slice in the fridge for 30 minutes to set.

Remove the caramel slice from the tin and cut it into 18 rectangles, approximately 9 x 2.8cm (3½ x 1¼ inches).

Store the slice in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

Next level

To add a little dazzle, rub some edible gold lustre dust into shaved or shredded coconut and sprinkle it on top of each bar.

Chocolate All Day: Recipes For Indulgence – Morning, Noon And Night by Kirsten Tibballs (£22, Murdoch Books) is out now

Photography: Armelle Habib

item.title: The best cult beauty buys that have stood the test of time
item.dc:creator: Chloe Burcham
item.content:encoded:
I’ve worked in the beauty industry for over 10 years, and trust me when I tell you that a lot of products have come and gone in that time. From social media sensations that blow up one week and are gone the next to niche indie brands that never really found their feet, when it comes to beauty products, only the very best stand the test of time.

Which is why many of these cult beauty buys have won countless awards over the years. From being used backstage at fashion shows by make-up artists and hairstylists to solidifying a space in my personal beauty cabinet for the last decade, these are the hardworking beauty heroes that really do deserve a place in your beauty arsenal…

Caudalie Beauty Elixir

Loved by the likes of Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and Victoria Beckham, this multipurpose mist helps to instantly hydrate, tighten pores and refresh make-up.

Shop Caudalie Beauty Elixir at Lookfantastic, £15

buy now

Nars Blush in Orgasm

This cult blusher shade has been around forever and continues to be a bestseller. The peachy pink shade suits all skin tones and infuses skin with a golden glow.

Shop Nars Blush in Orgasm, £30.50

buy now

Weleda Skin Food

An essential in every make-up artist’s kit, this multi-use cream is perfect for soothing areas of dryness or adding a gorgeous sheen to the skin. Katie Jane Hughes swears by it – and I’m sold.

Shop Weleda Skin Food at Boots, £14.95

buy now

Philip Kingsley Elasticizer Deep-Conditioning Treatment

Before the days of Olaplex and K18, it was all about Elasticizer. First developed for Audrey Hepburn back in the 1970s, it revives dehydrated, thirsty hair in just 20 minutes.

item.title: 9 new exhibitions in London to get your culture fix this month
item.dc:creator: Stylist Team
item.content:encoded:
Across London, pop-up exhibitions are taking place throughout the rest of the year, including a new Wes Anderson-inspired exhibition and Tate Britain’s Women In Revolt!

The seasonal change has brought about a new air in the capital, with plenty on offer for art lovers. Whether you’re a fashion history aficionado or you want to be immersed in the world of Monet, these are the shows to add to your cultural calendar over the next couple of months.

Accidentally Wes Anderson: The Exhibition

If you love Wes Anderson’s cinematic and colourful films, then you’ve probably come across the Accidentally Wes Anderson Instagram account, which has now also become a New York Times bestselling book. Highlighting the signature aesthetic of the director, this photography exhibition will transport you into the world of Anderson and you’ll even have the chance to make your very own Wes Anderson-esque moment.

Until 17 February 2024; £12.99; 81-85 Old Brompton Road, South Kensington, SW7 3LD

Women In Revolt! Art And Activism In The UK 1970–1990

This exhibition is an exploration of feminist art by over 100 women artists and spotlights how women used radical and rebellious ideas that helped fuel the women’s liberation movement during a period in history packed with social, economic and political change. Women In Revolt will be the first time many of the works have been on display to the public since the 1970s.

8 November–7 April 2024; £17; Tate Britain, Millbank, SW1P 4RG; tate.org.uk

Discover Liotard And The Lavergne Family Breakfast

Exploring famous paintings through a modern lens, the Discover series will spotlight the Swiss painter, Jean-Etienne Liotard, and his piece The Lavergne Family Breakfast. Comparing the pastel and oil versions of the paintings, this exhibition allows visitors to explore the differences in the two techniques as well as a rare look at the work – the painting was last exhibited in 1754.

16 November–3 March 2024; Free admission; The National Gallery; Trafalgar Square, WC2N 5DN; nationalgallery.org.uk

If Not Now, When?

Featuring 29 female sculptors from the 1960s to now, this exhibition is split into three chapters and explores time as an evolving cycle, reflecting the direct experiences and cycles of women. The three chapters are: women’s time (celebrating unique feminine values), tumbling through time (focusing on materiality and the sense that time is of the essence) and the time is now (addressing distinct moments in history).

15 November–22 January 2024; £10; Saatchi Gallery; King’s Road, SW3 4RY; saatchigallery.com

Greetings From Ireland

Presenting its 2023 fashion commission, NOW Gallery will host the new exhibition by Robyn Lynch and her menswear label titled Greetings From Ireland. Celebrating her Irish roots, the exhibition focuses on the designer’s creative process and the inspiration behind her fashion brand.

8 December–25 February 2024; Free admission; NOW Gallery, The Gateway Pavilions, SE10 0SQ; nowgallery.co.uk

Happy Gas

To celebrate four decades of Sarah Lucas’s thought-provoking, contemporary art, Tate Britain has collated some of her most iconic and captivating creations in this new exhibition, Happy Gas.

Her daring, bold and often provocative work is an exploration of sex, gender, class and humanity as demonstrated in her photography, spoken-word or eye-catching sculptures.

This exhibition is a fitting tribute to Lucas’s brash, bright and striking designs that have inspired others for over 40 years.

28 September - 14 January; £17; Tate Britain, Millbank, SW1P 4RG; tate.org.uk

Gabrielle Chanel, Fashion Manifesto

Ever wondered about how the House of Chanel began? For the first time in the UK, the V&A is opening its doors for an insight into the French couturière in this exhibition about Gabrielle ‘Coco’ Chanel.

Walk through fashion history with this display of archival classic and chic Chanel outfits that established the style and evolution of the brand. This exhibition follows in the footsteps of equally stylish selections from Alexander McQueen and Dior, which offer a historic snapshot of these iconic designers.

16 September - 25 February 2024, £24, V&A South Kensington, Cromwell Road, London, SW7 2RL; vam.ac.uk

Monet: The Immersive Experience

Witness the breathtaking artwork of Claude Monet like never before, in this immersive experience this autumn.

With a 360-degree digital projection of Monet’s famous Water Lilies series, step into the vivid landscape, walk over the flower-adorned footbridge and soak up the peaceful atmosphere inside the heart of the artist’s beloved work.

Through a VR experience, you can explore the inspiration behind his eight masterpieces including Poppies and Haystacks at the end of summer. Don’t miss out on this chance to get up close to Monet’s intricate paintings in this inspired exhibition.

Until January 2024; £14.90; Boiler House, 152 Brick Lane, E1 6RU; monetexpo.com

Rubens & Women

This exhibition explores the relationship between Flemish artist Peter Paul Rubens and the powerful women who inspired him.

Over 40 paintings and drawings will be brought together to showcase the nuance and wide-ranging portraits of women he created throughout his lifetime, to view the artist in a new light.

From imaginary muses to the countless impressions of his wives and children, this collection will summarise his faith, great loves and offer a sneak peek at private artwork alongside his masterpieces. This will be the first time that some of Rubens’ art has been showcased in the UK, so don’t miss a chance to see it for yourself.

27 September - 28 January 2024; £16.50 (free for members); Dulwich Picture Gallery; London, SE21 7AD; dulwichpicturegallery.org.uk

Images: Gina Birch; NOW Gallery; The National Gallery; Christine Kowal; Sarah Lucas COOL CHICK BABY, 2020. Collection of Alexander V. Petalas. Courtesy of the artist and Sadie Coles HQ, London © Sarah Lucas

item.title: 3 warming, nutrient-packed breakfast recipes to help you start your day off on the right foot
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Getting out of bed at this time of year can be tough. When it’s cold, dark and lashing with rain, the last thing you want is to swap the warmth of your duvet for the icy temperatures outside. But if there’s one thing that’s guaranteed to make getting up a little easier, it’s a delicious, warming breakfast.

Not only can the right breakfast help you to start the day off on the right foot, but it can also provide you with a solid energy boost – ideal if you’re struggling with your sleep now the clocks have gone back and SAD season is upon us.

So, to give you some autumnal breakfast inspiration, we’ve put together this selection of three tasty and warm breakfast recipes that are packed full of energy to help you smash the day.

<\h2>

There’s nothing quite like a big bowl of porridge to warm you up on a dark, cold morning, and this concoction from Carl White of Nopi, Ottolenghi’s Soho-based restaurant, is one you won’t want to miss. Devised for Rude Health, this recipe sees sweet and salty oats piled with fresh fruit, coconut shavings and mixed nuts. Delicious.

Ingredients

For the bircher:

  • 200ml coconut milk
  • 100g oats
  • 2 eating apples, coarsely grated
  • 50g mixed seeds (such as sunflower, pumpkin, sesame and linseed)
  • 25g mixed nuts (such as walnuts, brazil nuts, almonds and cashews)
  • 1 tsp ground cinnamon
  • 200ml cold water

For the miso butterscotch:

  • 150g white miso paste, at room temperature
  • 50ml mirin
  • 30g light brown sugar
  • 2 tsp sherry vinegar
  • 40g unsalted butter, at room temperature

For the toppings:

  • 40g mango, peeled and cut into large cubes
  • 40g apple, peeled and cut into large cubes
  • 40g pomegranate seeds
  • 20g toasted coconut shavings
  • 30g mixed nuts (such as walnuts, brazil nuts, almonds and cashews)
  • Baby basil

To finish:

  • 200g coconut milk
  • 140g light brown sugar
  • Pinch of salt

Method

  1. Preheat the oven to 160°C/gas mark 3
  2. Make the miso butterscotch using a rubber spatula to spread the miso paste out thinly and evenly on a parchment-lined baking tray. Place the tray in the oven and roast for 20-25 minutes until the miso has turned to a dark caramel, where the sides look burnt and the middle a dark golden brown.
  3. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool. Scrape the burnt miso paste off the parchment paper, breaking it as you go, and transfer the pieces to a food processor along with the mirin, sugar, vinegar, butter and one tablespoon of water. Blitz well for five minutes to form a smooth aerated paste.
  4. To make the bircher, put together the porridge oats, mixed seeds, half of the mixed nuts, cinnamon and the grated apple into a mixing bowl. Add 200ml of both coconut drink and cold water, mix well, then put into a sealed container and leave for two hours or overnight.
  5. Put the other 200ml of coconut drink, light brown sugar and 40g of the miso butterscotch into a pan to warm through then add your Bircher. Stir for 3-4 minutes on a medium heat until it’s nice and creamy.
  6. Spoon the porridge into three bowls. Divide the mango, apple, pomegranate seeds, toasted coconut shavings and the rest of the mixed nuts into each bowl and garnish with the baby basil.

<\h2>

If you’re more of a savoury breakfast fan, then this mushroom flatbread recipe designed by chef Juliet Sear for More With Mushrooms is the perfect option. The tahini in the dressing provides a source of protein and antioxidants, while the mushrooms are a good source of vitamin D. Packed with flavour and plenty of plants, this recipe is ideal for enjoying on long Sunday mornings.

Ingredients

For the mushroom flatbread:

  • 1 tbsp sunflower oil
  • 450g portobello mushrooms, cut into slices about 1 cm thickness
  • 2 large garlic cloves, crushed
  • ½ tsp smoked paprika
  • ½ tsp cumin seeds
  • Large pinch of chilli flakes
  • Small bunch of coriander or parsley leaves to garnish
  • Zest and juice of half a lime (plus extra wedges for slices)
  • 4 large flatbreads

For the tahini dressing:

  • 1 garlic clove, crushed
  • 90g tahini
  • 50ml lime juice
  • 2-3 tbsp water
  • Small bunch of coriander or parsley leaves to garnish
  • Sea salt to taste

For the tomato salsa (to serve alongside):

  • ¼ red onion, diced and extra slices to garnish
  • 200g mixed tomatoes, chopped slightly chunkier than finely diced
  • ½ a lime juiced
  • Large handful of coriander
  • 1 tsp Tabasco sauce
  • Pinch of sea salt flakes

<\h2>

Give your oats a bit more bite by baking them into this fruity recipe from Rowse Honey. The redcurrants add a powerful punch of antioxidants and vitamin C, while the apples and pear deliver a healthy dose of fibre. And because these baked oats serve six, they’re perfect for enjoying with friends or meal-prepping for the entire week.

Ingredients

  • 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
  • 2 large, sweet apples, thinly sliced
  • 1 pear, thinly sliced
  • A handful of redcurrants
  • 300 ml milk
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1 tsp ground cinnamon
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 240g porridge oats
  • 1 tbsp brown sugar
  • 3 tbsp acacia honey

Method

  1. Preheat your oven to around 180 degrees and if you don’t have a cast-iron skillet, lightly grease a baking dish.
  2. In a cast-iron skillet or frying pan, melt the unsalted butter over medium heat. Add the thinly sliced apples and pear, with a sprinkle of cinnamon, then continue to stir until they are tender and golden. Turn off and leave aside.
  3. In a separate bowl, combine the milk and eggs with ground cinnamon. Then, add in the porridge oats and baking powder. Finally, sprinkle in the redcurrants and stir in the golden goodness of acacia honey. Mix until the mixture is fully combined.
  4. Scoop your apple and pear mixture into the oats and fold through until distributed evenly.
  5. Pour the apple, pear, and oat mixture into your cast-iron skillet or baking dish. Sprinkle the brown sugar over the top for a sugary crunch.
  6. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes until the edges are golden brown.
  7. Finish with extra redcurrants and a generous drizzle of acacia honey, then slice to enjoy!

Images: Rude Health/Steve Ryan/Rowse Honey

item.title: The difference between physiotherapy, osteopathy and sports massage – and how to tell which one is for you
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
If you’re in pain, seeking expert help is a good place to start.

Whether you’ve got a niggle in your knee after a half marathon or you’ve strained your back lifting in the gym, getting your injury diagnosed and treated can speed up your healing time and prevent you from making things worse.

However, while deciding to seek help may be easy, knowing where and from whom to seek that help can be a little trickier. The number of clinics on offer aside, working out what kind of expert your injury requires can be difficult if you’re not familiar with the terminology.

So, to help you work your way through the jargon, we’ve put together this simple guide that explains the difference between physiotherapy, osteopathy and sports massage, and looks at the injuries and conditions each one is designed to help.

<\h2>

To find out more about each of the three, we asked Claire Small, chief clinical officer and consultant physiotherapist at Pure Sports Medicine, to explain a bit more.

Physiotherapy

We’ve all heard of physiotherapy in some form or another, but what does a physiotherapist do? “Physiotherapy is a medical service with a broad understanding of different conditions,” Small explains. “It looks at your musculoskeletal system, working to support it to perform in the best way so you’re able to do the activities you want to do pain-free.”

While physiotherapists may do some hands-on therapy – manipulating different parts of the body and helping to aid movement – a lot of the treatment tends to be movement and exercise-led, Small adds.

Osteopathy

The reason why many of us often get physiotherapy and osteopathy mixed up is that they share a lot of similarities, especially in their areas of focus.

“Osteopathy is a medical service that also looks at your musculoskeletal system, and has a lot of crossover with physiotherapy,” Small explains. “However, you can expect more manual and hands-on therapy within the treatments of osteopathy.”

This hands-on approach often means osteopathy is more session-based, while physiotherapy is a combination of in-house sessions and at-home rehabilitation. Osteopathy also tends to adopt a more holistic approach, looking at how the different parts of the musculoskeletal system work together, so it’s often used to address issues in the back and spinal area as opposed to arm and leg joints.

Sports massage

Sports massage, while still a medical service, is more concerned with treating tension and pain as opposed to understanding the route of the issue. Because of this, it’s often used to support or supplement physiotherapy and osteopathy treatment.

“Massage therapy, also called soft tissue massage therapy, allows the muscles to release tension or stiffness, which then allows you to move more freely and with a better range of motion,” Small says.

Sports massage can be used both pre- and post-exercise to help speed up recovery and reduce your risk of injury by ensuring the muscles are relaxed and tension-free.

<\h2>

The kind of treatment that will work best for you depends on whether you’re injured or just dealing with a lot of tension.

“You might see a physiotherapist or osteopath if you have sustained an injury or are in pain, while you may see a massage therapist if you are training for or have completed a race or event, have tightness or tension or have a lack of movement in an area of your body,” Small says.

“You might also see a massage therapist if you’re pregnant or if you’ve recently had a baby. Or you may get regular massage therapy to support your ongoing physical wellbeing and sporting goals.”

Deciding between an osteopath and a physiotherapist can be tricky, but keep in mind that osteopaths tend to be a bit more hands-on and adopt a more holistic approach, while physiotherapy is usually more targeted and involves at-home rehabilitation.

However, says Small, more important than picking a specific discipline is the clinician you’re booking to see. You want to not only ensure that your clinician is up to date with the latest research and using a range of techniques in your treatment – including manual therapy, exercise prescription and education – but also that they have expertise in the area you need.

“Many clinicians today are employed on skills and specialist basis, meaning they have committed themselves to certain injuries,” Small explains. “In these instances, their expertise is more important than their title; in the same way that GPs have different areas of interest, the same is true in this area of medicine.”

<\h2>

While it’s possible to seek help for sports injuries and conditions through the NHS, some people opt to seek treatment privately to speed up the process. In cases such as this, it’s important to keep a few things in mind while searching for an expert, Small says.

Below is a checklist of things she recommends looking into both before and during treatment. Your clinician should:

  • ask you why you are seeking treatment, what you expect of the clinician and what you want to get from the consultation
  • allow you to tell your story
  • explain the problem and ensure you understand what is being said
  • discuss different treatment options and the various implications of these and allow you to decide together what the most suitable course of action is (a process known as shared decision-making)
  • outline and discuss a treatment plan with you that works towards you achieving your goals, including what they will suggest if your condition fails to respond
  • if you aren’t improving, discuss options for second opinions

“If people aren’t getting this from the clinician they are seeing – it doesn’t matter if they are a physio, an osteopath or a massage therapist – they are not following the latest evidence and, at the very least, the patient should feel they can question the care they are receiving – or seek a second opinion,” Small says.

“Like every other profession and customer service industry out there, there are great physios, osteopaths and sports massage therapists, but there are also very poor ones. Good clinical care requires people to stay up to date with new developments.”

Images: Getty

item.title: How to nail the balletcore trend from top to toe
item.dc:creator: Soraya Gaied Chortane

Cast your mind back to circa 2006, when Kate Moss pirouetted the pavements of Primrose Hill in a pair of ballet slippers and we all rushed out to pick up our own pink-toned pairs. Eventually, the craze died down in favour of the classic white trainer, but fast forward to today and dancewear is, yet again, well and truly dominating our wardrobes.

From Bella Hadid in knitted legwarmers to Hailey Bieber, Doja Cat and Jennifer Lawrence strolling around on their morning coffee run in pretty pointe flats, you’d be hard pressed to find an it-girl that hasn’t leant into the balletcore trend this year.

And the autumn/winter 2023 runways boasted many a ballet-inspired take, with designers including Simone Rocha, Molly Goddard and Sandy Liang setting the barre with pretty hair ribbons, ballerina slippers and swoon-worthy sheer tulle dresses. But it was a certain pair of pink ribbon-tied buckled ballerina pumps, debuted by Miu Miu back in 2016, that truly reaffirmed our love of the shoe.

Meanwhile, All Saints has recently dropped a dreamy dance-inspired collaboration with the Royal Ballet, inviting four members from the renowned company’s troupe to select their six favourite pieces from their recent collection.

It’s a looser take on the ballerina affair, with elevated staples — more for the ‘off-duty’ dancer who traipses from home to her studio in an oversized hoody, high-impact boots and heavy-duty biker jackets.

“To be a ballet dancer you have to have such strength and we are a strong brand,” Catherine Jobling Scorey, COO at All Saints, tells Stylist. “To me there is nothing cooler than a classic tutu dressed with a cool leather biker jacket.”

If you’re looking to nail the trend from top to toe, look no further than Stylist’s edit of the best ballet-inspired styles to shop. From tights, leg warmers, wrap cardigans and a whole load of ballet flats, these are all the essentials you’ll need to help perfect your plié.

item.title: Made a mistake at work? Here’s how to apologise with the AAA method
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
It doesn’t matter how brilliant you are at your job, you will, at some point, make a mistake. It’s inevitable. Mess-ups come for us all. Your mistake might be tiny (a ‘reply all’ to an email, for example) or it could be a mighty wrong, but you can rest assured, there will be a moment where you err.

The key to success is not in trying to avoid mistakes at all costs (because that’s impossible – nobody’s perfect), but in apologising readily and bouncing back swiftly. That not only requires releasing your pride, but also the ability to deliver a really good apology.

The good news is that this is an ability you can absolutely pick up. Not sure where to start? Communications expert Matt Abrahams recommends something he calls the AAA technique.

“Saying sorry might seem like a straightforward thing, but there’s a bit of an art to it,” Abrahams notes. “Today, we’re breaking down a simple yet super-effective formula that can help you ace your apology game – the AAA technique. Think of it as your go-to toolkit for fixing things up and smoothing over those little bumps.

“In a nutshell, the AAA method is your ticket to saying sorry in a way that actually means something. It might not be a one-size-fits-all thing, but Acknowledge, Appreciate and Amends are the secret sauce for crafting apologies that fix things up and keep your connections strong.”

Here’s how to do the AAA method.

<\h2>

“First off, we need to own up to our blunders,” says Abrahams. “No beating around the bush here. It’s time to point out exactly what we did wrong and take full responsibility without any fancy footwork.

“So, instead of saying something like, ‘sorry if what I said offended you’, let’s get real with it:

  • ‘My bad for waiting until the last minute to test the system. I know it messed with our workflow.’
  • ‘I shouldn’t have called out your commitment in front of everyone. I’m sorry for making you look bad.’

“Cut the jargon and get straight to the point—that’s the ticket!”

<\h2>

Have a think about exactly how your mistake has impacted other people and make it clear that you understand this. Make reference to the emotions at play, not just what happened.

“We’re talking about putting ourselves in their shoes and realising the emotional toll our blunders took,” Abrahams explains. “Avoid downplaying the impact. Instead of saying, ‘it’s not a big deal’, let’s be real:

  • ‘The software upgrade mess definitely ate into your work time, and I feel bad about it.’
  • ‘Calling you out like that? I get it now – it made you look bad. My bad for real.’

“Feel their feelings and let them know you get why they’re upset.”

<\h2>

“Now comes the part where we talk about what we’re going to do to make things right,” Abrahams concludes. “It’s not just about saying sorry; it’s about showing you’re serious about making things better.

“Skip the vague promises and get specific:

  • ‘To avoid this mess again, I’m committing to testing the system an hour before our demos, starting next week.’
  • ‘If I’ve got issues with your work, I’ll talk to you privately from now on. No more public call-outs.’

“Concrete steps show you’re not just talking the talk; you’re walking the walk.”

Matt Abrahams is a lecturer at Stanford Graduate School of Business and author of Think Faster, Talk Smarter: How To Speak Successfully When You’re Put On The Spot.

item.title: How to schmooze at work: the 5 essential rules of good small talk
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
There are two types of people in the world: those for whom the mere mention of small talk inspires dread and despair, and those who take to it like a duckling to a warm bath. 

If you fall into the former camp, it’s quite frustrating that the act of small talk seems to make up so much of our workplace interactions. An ability to have a chit-chat can feel more essential than Excel skills; it’s a necessity for landing a job, networking, getting a promotion, getting in your boss’s good books… the list goes on and on. 

We tend to think of the gift of the gab as something innate, but the truth is that having good chat is a skill that can be built. How, you may ask? That’s where Matt Abrahams comes in. 

Abrahams is a lecturer at Stanford Graduate School of Business, the author of Think Faster, Talk Smarter: How to Speak Successfully When You’re Put on the Spot and Speaking Up Without Freaking Out, and the host of Think Fast, Talk Smart: The Podcast. In short, he is the true expert when it comes to communication in the world of work. 

“In the intricate dance of social interactions, the ability to engage in meaningful small talk – or as some like to call it, schmoozing – can be a game-changer,” he tells Stylist. “Whether you’re navigating a networking event, mingling at a party or just striking up a conversation with a colleague, mastering the art of schmoozing can open doors and create lasting connections.”

Abrahams says there are five simple rules to great small talk, which he shares ahead. 

<\h2>

Abrahams says: “You know that person who can’t stop talking about themselves? Yeah, don’t be that person. The key to successful small talk is putting the spotlight on the other party. People love to share their stories, so let them. Ask open-ended questions, listen actively, and show genuine interest. Trust me, when you make it about them, you become the person everyone wants to talk to.”

This approach can also help you deal with nerves. When you’re feeling anxious about how you’re coming across, switch the focus to the other person. Think about how you can make them feel more comfortable, and you’ll often find that your own discomfort slips away.

<\h2>

It’s tempting to prep a list of icebreakers and fun facts so you’ll feel more prepared for a big socialising session, but this isn’t the way to form a genuine connection. Instead, go in with some topics in mind and curate the structure of your conversation to make the other person feel heard.

“My favorite formula for this is What, So What, Now What,” Abrahams recommends. “Start with a point or argument (What), add significance to it (So What), and suggest a course of action or inquire about theirs (Now What). It’s like a mini storytelling session that keeps the conversation flowing and engaging. Craft your content and you’ll never be at a loss for words.”

<\h2>

“Let’s be real – the standard ‘how are you?’ can lead to the most yawn-inducing loop of conversations,” says Abrahams. “Break free from the mundane! When initiating small talk, skip the clichés.

“Comment on the environment, share a quirky observation or ask about their thoughts on a relevant topic. Be the conversation starter who adds a spark to the chat. Trust me; it’s way more interesting than the usual script.”

<\h2>

No one wants to be stuck in a chat with someone that just won’t end. The answer is not just pretending you need the loo or darting your eyes around the room hoping to spot someone you recognise. Instead, try the ‘white flag’ approach.

“This is all about leaving on a high note,” Abrahams explains. “Express gratitude for the conversation, show you’ve been engaged, and end with a thoughtful question. It could be about their experiences, opinions, or even recommendations. This way, you’re not just exiting; you’re leaving a positive and lasting impression.”

<\h2>

“Here’s a secret: nobody’s perfect, especially in small talk,” says Abrahams. “Embrace the imperfections, and you’ll feel the weight lift off your shoulders. Small talk is a two-way street; it’s not just about what you say but how you make others feel. If you stumble on your words or say something offbeat, laugh it off. Small talk is about building connections, not delivering a flawless monologue. Be authentic, be yourself and watch the magic happen.”

item.title: What weight should I be lifting? PTs explain how to choose the right weights at the gym
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gray
item.content:encoded:
Even if you’ve been strength training a while, weights rooms can feel super intimidating. You might have spent the past few months chest pressing and deadlifting in your living room, but suddenly, you’re faced with way more weight options. The key to overcoming gym anxiety is to have a plan in place before you even step through the front door – but if you’re not sure which weights to go for, that can be a little difficult.

To help make that decision a little easier, we’ve roped in PTs Alice Miller and Zara Ozard who know all about creating a sustainable, effective gym regime. Not sure where to begin on your weight lifting journey, or how to translate your home practice in the weights room? Keep on reading…

<\h2>

“For most people, choosing the right weight will require a little trial and error,” says Ozard. “I always say that the weight you’re lifting should be challenging but doable. If your form is being compromised during both the lifting and lowering phase, then that would suggest that you’re lifting too heavy.”

She suggests choosing a weight that allows you to work for eight-to-12 reps per set, and which leaves your muscles feeling fatigued during the last couple of reps. “You might do your first set and know that you could get more out, in which case add some weight on for your next set. It’s also great to write things down so you can remember where you were last time and pick your weight accordingly.”

Miller agrees with Ozard that it’s really a personal choice. “It depends on how long you’ve been training, if you’ve taken breaks, if you’ve got injuries and what your goals are. If you are completely new, I would focus on getting used to using dumbbells. They are a great way to start out on your lifting journey.

“You want to make sure that you’re not lifting so heavy that you can’t control your form, but also need to lift something that feels challenging. A 2kg dumbbell is probably lighter than your backpack, so don’t be shy about trying heavier!”

<\h2>

Now, you might think that weight trianing is all about lifting as heavy as you can – but head to a spin session or pilates class, and you’ll find instructors using really light dumbbells. Both kinds of weights can burn, which is better to choose if you’re on your own in the gym?

“It depends on the goal but if you’re totally new to training, I’d suggest doing lighter weights for more reps until you have the form perfect, rather than jumping in to heavy weights and injuring yourself,” Ozard says.

“If your goal is strength, choose a weight you can only lift for a maximum of six reps. Muscular endurance, on the other hand, happens around the 15 rep mark, so you’ll need much lighter dumbbells.”

Miller, however, says that she believes “every single person should be lifting heavy”.

That means lifting around 80% of your one rep max – ie the heaviest you could possibly squat just once. If you don’t know what that is yet, then Miller recommends using ‘rate of perceived exertion’, which is an effort ranking between one and 10. “Lifting heavy would probably be an eight, nine or 10, on that scale, with nine being the feeling of ‘that’s really heavy but I could probably do one more rep’ and 10 being ‘I am maxed out, I can’t do anything more’.”

Why so heavy? Miller flags that the body won’t adapt if it’s not being surprised or stressed, so gradually adding more weight every few training sessions is going to help you progress.

<\h2>

OK, so we’re committed to lifting a little more than usual. But given how important form is, it’s important to know exactly how to lift heavier.

Go slow

Miller stresses the importance to gradually getting heavier: “Work on consistency and focus on the basics. That means learning to move well. My advice is to go a little bit slower and so you can really focus on that control. Think about what muscles are being worked when you’re doing it.”

Remember to breathe

“Something that people kind of forget about is how powerful your breath is when doing strength work,” she continues. “If you don’t work with your breath and if you’re not creating tension in your body, you’re not going to be able to lift as much. All the great strength coaches are going to teach you about intra-abdominal pressure and creating that tension in the midline.”

Be consistent

Ozard says that “you also need to be training quite regularly, but also with enough time out to rest and recover”.

Focus on your core

“Having a strong core is also important because when we lift everything comes from the core,” Ozard concludes.

Images: Getty

item.title: Anne Hathaway says she was told her career would ‘fall off a cliff’ by 35
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
As an Academy Award-winner and the much-loved star of The Princess Diaries, The Devil Wears Prada and Interstellar, it’s hard to believe that Anne Hathaway could be thought of as anything other than entertainment royalty.

But in a recent interview with Porter, the actor recalled that when she first started out in Hollywood, she was told that her career wouldn’t last. “I was warned that my career would fall off a cliff at the age of 35, which is something I know a lot of women face,” she explained.

In an industry where ageism, particularly towards women, remains rife, it’s saddening but not surprising. Halle Berry is constantly standing up to age-shamers online, while Naomi Watts has gone public about being told she needed to achieve as much as possible in her acting career before becoming “unfuckable” over the age of 40.

However, as 41-year-old Hathaway pointed out, an increasing number of women in the industry are now (thankfully) enjoying longer careers than in the past.

“The thing that has evolved during (that time) is that more women are having careers deeper into their lives, which I think is fantastic,” she shared. “Obviously, it doesn’t mean we should have a ticker-tape parade – someone said this to me the other day: ‘There’s so much to be proud of and there’s so much to fix.’”

Elsewhere in the interview, Hathaway opened up about having “always been really upfront about being an ambitious person”, adding, “I have goals, I have dreams; they don’t look much different than they did when I was (younger), but I’m still pursuing them.”

A masterclass in never giving up if we’ve ever seen one.

Images: Getty

item.title: Niksen is the Dutch lifestyle trend that celebrates doing absolutely nothing
item.dc:creator: Megan Murray
item.content:encoded:
From political turbulence to the climate crisis and the rising cost of living, 2023 has been a challenging year to say the least. The state of the world has left us frustrated, anxious and, frankly, exhausted, meaning that as we approach Christmas and New Year, finding time to truly wind down is key.

Luckily, there is one Dutch lifestyle trend that is all about tackling the increasing levels of stress and burnout felt by modern generations and taking time to chill out.

Picked up by Time Magazine, Niksen is a word used by the Dutch to encapsulate the combined feeling and activity of doing absolutely nothing, with zero levels of purpose. Now, it doesn’t have to mean sitting still exactly but is used for those times when your mind wanders, you may be pottering about at home, taking your time and without the burden of feeling like you need to achieve anything.

Although the Netherlands has obviously been using the word for hundreds of years, it seems like the perfect time for it to migrate over to the UK, as burnout becomes a growing problem.

Not to be confused with anxiety or depression, burnout is a state of extreme stress when the body goes into auto-pilot, leaving you feeling like a robot. It can creep up on us slowly, masked by a sense of ‘we’re all busy though, aren’t we?’ and seems to be a particularly millennial problem, caused essentially by taking on too much and a need to high performing at everything.

Niksen, by contrast, celebrates the joy of doing nothing and letting the world glide on past. Like a form of self-care, by practising niksen it is thought that we give our minds and bodies the chance to really, truly unwind.

How you ‘niks’ is up to you, and the joy of being idle is a very personal thing, so it’s unlikely that you’ll relish doing nothing in the same way as a friend. Below, though, we’ve picked out four ways you can start practicing some niksen time if you’re not sure how to get started.

Sit by a window and just stare

No, seriously. The act of just curling up in a chair and sitting for a minute, with nowhere to be and nothing to do is exactly what niksen is all about. This is even better done when there’s a window to look out of, so that you can literally sit and watch the world go by.

Lie on your bed and listen to music

Niksen should be nothing if not comfortable, and is there a more comfortable place than bed? We’d be hard pushed to find one if there is. Lying back and just letting your mind wander, with some of your favourite tunes on in the background is a great way to unfurl from the stress of your day. Don’t feel guilty about doing nothing, just enjoy doing nothing.

Go for a walk

Now when we say go for a walk, we don’t mean anywhere in particular, the point of niksen is to achieve absolutely nothing. So if you have some spare time, or better yet, you’ve set aside some time to niksen, then why not take a stroll to nowhere, in particular, to clear your mind and just be.

Do something with your hands like knitting or a jigsaw

Again, we’re not asking you to work hard on a knitting pattern to whip up a new scarf for your great-aunt. This act of just doing something with your hands should feel almost therapeutic like you’re just doing it for the sake of it without a wider agenda.

If you’re loving learning about lifestyle trends from Scandinavia and the Netherlands, check out all the ways you can use hygge to improve your life at home and at work here.

item.title: 8 new festive Christmas films coming this winter
item.dc:creator: Meg Walters
item.content:encoded:
With December fast approaching, it’s almost time to get in the festive mood. Soon enough, we’ll be pulling out the advent calendars, putting up the fairy lights and throwing on our comfiest jumpers. The final ingredient? A cosy festive flick.

Of course, we all know and love the classics, from Elf and Love Actually to The Holiday. However, if you’ve already watched and rewatched all of the holiday staples, you may be in the mood for something new.

So, here are eight brand new wintry films to keep an eye out for this season.

Best. Christmas. Ever!

This is already a classic in the making: starring Brandy, singer and star of cult classic Cinderella, and 00s icon Heather Graham, Best. Christmas. Ever! follows two old friends, Jackie (Brandy) and Charlotte (Graham), who find themselves spending Christmas together along with their two families when Charlotte sets out to prove that her old friend’s seemingly picture-perfect life can’t be as idyllic as it appears.

Best. Christmas. Ever! will be streaming on Netflix from 16 November.

Candy Cane Lane

Starring comedy legend Eddie Murphy and black-ish’s Tracee Ellis Ross, Candy Cane Lane promises to be old-school festive comedy fare. The film follows Chris Carver (Murphy), who makes a deal with a magical elf to win his neighbourhood Christmas decoration context. However, when the elf turns out to be evil, he has to find a way to stop her (and probably save Christmas in the process).

Candy Cane Lane will be streaming on Prime Video from 1 December.

Your Christmas Or Mine 2

Sequel alert: Your Christmas Or Mine 2 follows James (Asa Butterfield) and Hayley (Cora Kirk). who are gearing up for their second Christmas as a couple. And that can only mean one thing… mayhem with their families.

This time around, James’ dad has invited the family to spend Christmas in a luxury ski resort in the Austrian Alps, so they can meet his new American girlfriend (played by Jane Krakowski). However, Hayley’s dad Geoff insisted on handling his family’s side of the booking and something clearly got lost in translation. After a mix-up with transport at the airport, the two tribes end up at each other’s accommodations, on different sides of a valley and opposite ends of the Tripadvisor ratings scale. Can Hayley and James’ relationship survive another turbulent family Christmas, or has their future together gone off-piste?

Your Christmas Or Mine 2 will launch on Friday 8 December on Prime Video.

The Velveteen Rabbit

OK, get ready to feel very, very nostalgic, because the famous children’s story The Velveteen Rabbit is finally getting a live-action adaptation. Margery Williams’s story tells the tale of a stuffed rabbit made of velveteen, who, after being given to a little boy for Christmas, dreams of becoming a real rabbit – something that can only happen when his owner’s love for him is real. You’ll hear the voices of Helena Bonham-Carter, Nicola Coughlan, Alex Lawther and Paterson Joseph as the toys, while the mother is played by Samantha Colley.

The Velveteen Rabbit will be streaming on Apple TV+ from 22 November.

The Holdovers

An acclaimed Christmas comedy, The Holdovers is set in a 1970s New England boarding school, where strict history teacher Paul (Paul Giamatti) is left to take care of four ‘holdover’ students over Christmas, while the rest of the school returns home for the holidays. Although Paul tries to run a tight ship, things soon go awry.

The Holdovers is coming to cinemas on 19 January 2024.

Family Switch

The swapping places comedy is a whole subgenre of its own, with classics like Freaky Friday, The Parent Trap and The Princess Switch. Now, there’s a new addition with Family Switch, which sees Jennifer Garner and Ed Helms playing two parents who switch places with their children, played by Brady Noon and Wednesday’s Emma Myers. To make matters more exciting, the mystical switch takes place right before the holidays. Any opportunity to see Jennifer Garner playing a 13-year-old stuck in the body of an adult, sign us up.

Family Switch will be streaming on Netflix from 30 November.

Dashing Through the Snow

Coming to Disney+ this season, Dashing Through the Snow is a comedy fantasy about a man who hates Christmas after a difficult childhood. When he and his daughter meet a man called ‘Nick’ on Christmas Eve, things soon take a magical twist.

Dashing Through the Snow is streaming from 17 November.

What Happens Later

Finally, we’ve got What Happens Later, a brand new romcom starring and directed by Meg Ryan, the queen of the genre. Ryan and David Duchovny play exes who run into each other during the holidays at an airport. Stuck together overnight, the pair finally gets the chance to discuss what happened between them.

What Happens Later hit cinemas in October 2023. Its streaming release has yet to be announced.

Image: Apple TV+

item.title: Can't stop daydreaming? A new study suggests it might actually be linked to anxiety
item.dc:creator: Meg Walters
item.content:encoded:
Often find yourself daydreaming? Your eyes drifting away from your computer screen or the dirty dishes in front of you as you lose yourself in an indulgent fantasy? The good news is, a little daydreaming is completely normal. In fact, it can even be good for you. But why are some people more prone to it than others? And what does it mean if you have daydreams that you can’t seem to control?

According to a new study from researchers in Toyko, having a tendency to daydream may actually be linked to your curiosity or to your anxiety. Or maybe even to both!

About the study

Researchers conducted two separate studies to examine how curiosity and anxiety both play a part in how (and when) we daydream.

In the first study, they surveyed 260 students to find out about their daydreaming habits, their curiosity type, and their anxiety levels. They found that people with anxiety were more likely to drift off into daydreams without being able to control the mind’s wandering.

The second study looked more closely at diversive curiosity (the type of curiosity that leads people to be interested in a wide range of subjects). Similarly, the study found that people who were more curious about diverse topics found themselves daydreaming both on purpose and by accident more frequently. In individuals with anxiety, the levels of accidental daydreaming were higher.

The takeaway

So, what does all of this mean? Well, firstly, it suggests that your daydreaming patterns might hint at both your curiosity and your anxiety levels. It’s important to note that controllable daydreaming (daydreaming that you decide to do) is not a strong indicator of anxiety. However, if you often find yourself drifting off into daydreams unintentionally, it might be linked to heightened anxiety. But, it also might suggest you simply have a very active, curious mind.

If you’re struggling with feelings of anxiety or with uncontrollable daydreaming, it’s always recommended to speak to a mental health professional who can help.

Images: Getty

item.title: “I’m at peace with being estranged from my mum – so why does it make everyone else so uncomfortable?”
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
item.content:encoded:
I tap on my Instagram and go to Blocked Accounts, and there her account appears. She is smiling, head tilted and framed in a perfect circle. A green dot glowing towards the bottom left tells me she is currently active. This is my estranged mother; I haven’t spoken to her in years.

I am at peace with this arrangement, and I believe she is too. But many onlookers are not. Maternal estrangement makes them feel uncomfortable. ‘But she’s your mum…’, ‘You’ve only got one’ and ‘Oh, you two will reconnect at some point’ are the usual responses. The implication is that this is a situation that requires fixing and reconciliation is the only remedy.

I’m one of many adult daughters who are estranged from their mothers. We are a silent group, but a cohort that could be on the rise. Up to 10% of mothers are estranged from at least one adult child, with academic researchers and therapists saying that they’re witnessing a ‘silent epidemic’ of family breakups more generally. In the UK, the charity Stand Alone estimates that one in five families will be touched by family estrangement and its consequences.

I wish there was more compassion and less judgment

It’s a group that Dr Joshua Coleman, a clinical psychologist and the author of Rules Of Estrangement, suspects is growing. “There’s a rise due to a number of factors. In the past half-century or so, there was an institutional framework that guided families, such as the church, gender, marriage and your neighbourhood. You had this idea that you should ‘honour thy mother, honour thy father’ and respect your elders. This has given way to a much more identitarian perspective about family living that is much more constituted around: what will make me happy? What’s in alignment with my ideals? Add to that increasing divorce rates, rising rates of individualism in Western societies and social media fanning the flames, and all of these things make families more at risk of estrangement.”

The mother-daughter estrangement, of all the family dyads, says Coleman, is “potentially the most fraught. Female identities are often more socialised towards relationship building and can carry more feelings of guilt and responsibility. So I think for daughters there can be a greater feeling of shame about it.”

It’s by no means unique to mothers and daughters. “Men get pressured to reconcile, but the pressure women experience is enormous,” says Helena Smith*. “My mother and I were estranged on and off for many years before our final estrangement three years before she died. I kept trying to make things right between us. I was also the one who made the decision to be estranged in the end. Quite honestly, by the time I did that, after decades of painful experiences, it came as a huge relief. It got rid of a huge ongoing source of anxiety and pain in my life. It brought me a level of peace. Of course, I was still sad about the fact that we couldn’t have a relationship; I still wished we could. But when I finally let go of actively working to ‘fix’ it, I felt better than I had in many years.”

I don’t grieve the loss of a relationship I never had

Zoe Louise

The commentary around ‘But she’s your mum’ feels loaded, like it’s heavy with gendered stigma. Swap it with ‘dad’ and it doesn’t have the same bite. “It baffles me because people will always say ‘But she’s your mum’, but you would never say ‘But they’re your abuser’ to someone,” says Zoe Louise, who is estranged from her mother. “I wish there was more compassion and less judgment.”

This idea of a mother as your ‘best friend’ is written in our greeting cards, Instagram captions and film scripts: ’Like mother, like daughter’, ‘First my daughter, forever my friend’. But it’s far from reality for many, says Becca Bland, a specialist coach in family estrangement. “These relationships can be damaging to one’s health and wellbeing. It can be impossible to imagine that a mother is unloving or uncaring. Yet women are humans and many will bring their unresolved pain and trauma into motherhood.”

“Perhaps it is the mythology of the mother figure that I feel is missing in my life rather than the reality. A big part of my journey has been grieving the mother I never had and accepting the mother I did get,” says Bland.

This maternal archetype can compound feelings of shame when your lived experience is just not the same. It feels like the ultimate taboo to admit. It’s the thing you try to swerve past on first dates or when you’re getting to know colleagues and friends. Even if you try to be open, just saying the word ‘estranged’ feels hard to get out of your throat. It can leave you reeling afterwards, fearing judgment. It keeps your mind whirring – Did I really do the right thing? Am I a bad person? – and feels like you’re hoarding a terrible secret.

What Dr Joshua Coleman is keen to emphasise is that estrangement can look very different for different people. There isn’t one blueprint. No contact can involve not meeting up physically, but still having a text exchange. It can be reconciling, then pulling away, then reconciling again. It can be no contact at all. It can be limiting meet-ups to once a year.

For Zoe Louise, her maternal estrangement feels “normal”. “That’s because I’ve never had a close relationship [with my mother]. I don’t really grieve the loss of a relationship I never had. The estrangement occurred as a result of my childhood traumas, specifically her abusive behaviour towards me, which meant that I never had a secure attachment to her. I grew up afraid of my mum; as soon as I gained independence, I left home and never sought out that bond.”

Grieving a mother who is alive comes without a guidebook. There’s no official accepted process. There’s no absolute like a loss. Both parties have to define their own sense of closure. That can change, and that’s OK. What may be right for one mother-daughter relationship simply isn’t for another. The best course of action is what you make of it.

Images: Getty

*Name changed for anonymity

item.title: 8 winter pop-ups and rooftops to book in London for the festive season
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
It’s no secret that Christmas is one of the busiest times of the year, but there’s still plenty of time to get our calendars in order and enjoy everything that the yuletide season has to offer. Whether you need inspiration for seasonal get-togethers with friends or you’re searching for the perfect cosy spot for an evening in the city, there’s a whole host of pop-ups across London that are sure to bring you tidings of comfort and joy.

From rooftop ice rinks to festive terraces, here are eight of the best events opening soon. Grab your friends and get booking.

Don Julio 1942 x Studio Frantzén Winter Terrace at Harrods

Don Julio tequila and Björn Frantzén have come together to create a new winter hot spot on the top floor of the famed department store. Expect warming fur blankets, festive drinks and stunning views of the city.

Address: 87-135 Brompton Rd, London SW1X 7XL

Book now

Skylight Tobacco Dock

Europe’s only real-ice rooftop ice rink is the perfect place to show off your skating skills – and then relax with a drink afterwards – throughout November and December.

Address: Tobacco Dock, London E1W 2SF

Book now

Christmas Midnight Apothecary roof garden

Enjoy campfire cocktails in an enchanted garden at the Christmas Midnight Apothecary roof garden and Underground Tour, exploring the likes of the Thames tunnel while sipping bespoke drinks.

Address: Railway Ave, London SE16 4LF

Book now

The Rooftop at Trafalgar St. James

Head to the iconic hotel’s seventh floor to find a winter cocktail list of warming and seasonal flavours for cold winter nights. Signature blends include the tequila-based Winter in Oaxaca, with flavours of pear, mole and chilli caramel, and the festive Maple Kiss, with pisco, red wine, maple spice, hibiscus and orange blossom.

Address: 7th Floor, 2 Spring Gardens, London SW1A 2TS

Book now

Winter igloos at Mercer Roof Terrace

Cuddle up with a blanket and take in magical views high above the city in a warm winter igloo, which can be booked for up to six guests.

Address: 20 Garlick Hill, London EC4V 2AU

Book now https://www.instagram.com/p/CygGmcnIDS9/?img_index=1

Skate at Somerset House
